Wilfried Wöber (wilfried.woeber@technikum-wien.at)
2019-10-29 02:58:00

Facing the one pixel attack or others (anything is an ostrich 🙂 ) or the work of Marcus at CoRR 2018 (Deep learning: A critical appraisal), I was wondering why CNNs are still used even in computational simple approaches where alternative models (bayes methods) or linear models (e.g.: PCA) would perform great. To me, it seems, that the simplicity of both, the math of aNN and the usability, leads to applications where GPU based CNN methods are not necessary... (In Austria we say: shoot for sparrows with cannons 🙂 ). I would like to hear your opinion. Any comments?

Laurens Hogeweg (laurens.hogeweg@naturalis.nl)
2019-10-29 03:29:20

@Wilfried Wöber for me one of the major advantages of CNNs is their ability to learn their own features, not something you easily get from other ML methods

Wilfried Wöber (wilfried.woeber@technikum-wien.at)
2019-10-29 08:01:07

@Laurens Hogeweg yeah that makes CNNs somehow sexy to use facing matrix-like struktures... On the other hand, graphical models or conditional exponential families are (theoretical) able to do similar stuff but are limited in terms of computational costs... To me, CNN application seems to have more practical advantages as statistical benefits. For example, Neal discussed that probabilistic MLP using infinite neurons becomes Gaussian processes.

Frederic (frederic@apic.ai)
2020-02-07 07:50:53

In case someone of you is interested in pose estimation of the western honey bee, check out our new dataset: https://github.com/apic-ai/apic-bee-pose-dataset

The apic.ai bee pose dataset contains annotation of 32 relevant keypoints on the western honey bees. Explicitly inferring the pose is beneficial for the identification of behavioral anomalies such as trembling after poisoning or infections.

👍 gvanhorn, Alayna Van Dervort, Subhransu Maji, Sara Beery, Elijah Cole (Deactivated), Stefan Schneider, Veith Röthlingshöfer, Manish Rai
🐝 gvanhorn, Sara Beery, Oisin Mac Aodha, Siyu Yang, Ben Weinstein, Stefan Schneider, Veith Röthlingshöfer, Tony Chang, Lily Xu, hieule, Björn Lütjens, Sam Kelly, Tee R.
🚶‍♂️ Jon Van Oast
Alayna Van Dervort (alaynavandervort@mac.com)
2020-02-07 09:04:09

This is fantastic! Congratulations.

Ben Weinstein (benweinstein2010@gmail.com)
2020-05-11 13:42:16

Anyone with more tf.data experience have an idea? Trying to catch individual corrupted files in tfrecords batches https://stackoverflow.com/questions/61735361/how-to-catch-and-raise-tfrecord-error-in-tf-dataset-map-in-tensorflow-2-0

Stack Overflow
How to catch and raise tfrecord error in tf.dataset.map in tensorflow &gt; 2.0
Using tfdataset (tensorflow &gt; 2.0) I encounter a rare corrupt file that cannot be cast into the correct dimensions. Each tfrecord line has a filename of an image to be read and the dimensions. I wa...
Original URL: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/61735361/how-to-catch-and-raise-tfrecord-error-in-tf-dataset-map-in-tensorflow-2-0
gvanhorn (grv22@cornell.edu)
2020-05-11 16:04:54

I use the following approach (this is taken from a file download script): ``` # Ignore the images that fail, we'll detect this by comparing all the images that succeeded with the full list of images. dataset = dataset.apply(tf.data.experimental.ignore_errors())

dataset = <a href="http://dataset.as">dataset.as</a>_numpy_iterator()

successful_downloads = []
for filename in tqdm(dataset, total=num_downloads, mininterval=3):
    successful_downloads.append(filename.decode())```
gvanhorn (grv22@cornell.edu)
2020-05-11 16:06:00

The idea is to ignore all errors and have your dataset return filenames. If a filename was returned then you can assume it was not corrupted

gvanhorn (grv22@cornell.edu)
2020-05-11 16:07:24

then I do a diff against all the filenames to find the corrupted ones

👍 Ben Weinstein
gvanhorn (grv22@cornell.edu)
2020-05-11 16:09:30

I’ve started to save the image files themselves using tensorflow in order to cut down on errors when I subsequently store those images into tfrecords for later experiments

👍 Sara Beery
Ben Weinstein (benweinstein2010@gmail.com)
2020-05-11 16:09:49

Thanks. I appreciate it.

gvanhorn (grv22@cornell.edu)
2020-05-11 16:09:57

```def savejpeg(imagebuffer, filename):

image = <a href="http://tf.io">tf.io</a>.decode_image(image_buffer, channels=3, dtype=tf.dtypes.uint8, expand_animations=False)
image_shape = tf.shape(image)
jpeg_buffer = <a href="http://tf.io">tf.io</a>.encode_jpeg(
    image,
    format='rgb',
    quality=95,
    progressive=False,
    optimize_size=False,
    chroma_downsampling=True,
    density_unit='in',
    x_density=300,
    y_density=300,
    xmp_metadata='',
    name=None
)

<a href="http://tf.io">tf.io</a>.write_file(filename, jpeg_buffer)

return filename```
👍 Siyu Yang, Mike Trizna

Armin Bazarjani (bazarjan@usc.edu)
2021-01-07 17:41:01

*Thread Reply:* I'm still learning the ropes, but I made the switch and I found it easier to pick up. I personally find it much easier to work with and debug. I also find dataloader in pytorch much more sophisticated than tfrecords or tfdata. I think the main argument for tf has been the enterprise features that it supports, but I'm not really interested in that as of now, and (don't quote me) I think pytorch has addressed that by now too. Granted, I'm not yet doing as advanced things as I presume you guys are doing so take my opinion with a grain of salt.

Ben Weinstein (benweinstein2010@gmail.com)
2021-01-07 17:43:01

*Thread Reply:* thanks. day 4 with it and liking it. I haven't gotten to the multi-gpu dataloader questions. I am worried I will miss tfrecords, my logic being that since pytorch is more python, it feels like it can't be as fast as binary read from tfrecords, but we will see. We have pretty big data.

Armin Bazarjani (bazarjan@usc.edu)
2021-01-07 17:55:58

*Thread Reply:* Nice! I can't comment on my own experience with it, but a researcher on a reddit exchange commented that his own benchmark tests showed pytorch dataloader to be as efficient as tensorflow tfrecords. But, I am interested to here how it goes for you as well. Good luck with everything!

Ben Weinstein (benweinstein2010@gmail.com)
2021-01-08 22:03:24

*Thread Reply:* Thanks. I guess my question is what strategies to use in pytorch to try to get similiar performance. Whether a dataloader will just get IO bottleneck because of the python GIL. Its all nice to be more readable because its python code, but i'm worried about scaling up training speed. No good to have multiple GPUs if you can't pipe data in fast enough.

👍 Alex Zhuang
Benjamin Kellenberger (benjamin.kellenberger@wur.nl)
2021-01-10 06:20:08

*Thread Reply:* @Ben Weinstein > I haven’t gotten to the multi-gpu dataloader questions. (…) I am worried I will miss tfrecords, my logic being that since pytorch is more python, it feels like it can’t be as fast as binary read from tfrecords, but we will see. In the past TF has been faster than PyTorch due to JIT C compilation. However, PyTorch now offers the same and speed differences are getting minuscule. Unlike TF, execution by default happens in Python, apart from core functions (e.g., convolutions and the autograd backward pass), which gives full transparency, but as said with JIT performance can be optimized.

Regarding multi-GPU training: the fastest way of doing that is to use the DistributedDataParallel wrapper (essentially a one-liner).

Regarding data loaders: I don’t know what TF records specify. Perhaps they’re optimized for speed, which is great. The PyTorch approach instead allows you to load, prepare, manipulate and return data records in any form you want. The standard way of doing is is to write a Dataset wrapper class that (i.) loads your data (images, etc.), (ii.) applies Transforms (built-in or any custom one) and returns data. The DataLoader class then accepts a dataset class instance and takes care of multi-threaded data loading. There’s no GIL here; PyTorch extends the Multiprocessing module and allows proper multi-threading (ﬂag num_workers in the DataLoader class).

Caleb Robinson (calebrob6@gmail.com)
2021-01-11 14:47:33

*Thread Reply:* There exists a library called PyTorch Lightning that helps with normal DL operations -- https://pytorch-lightning.readthedocs.io/en/stable/new-project.html

Björn Lütjens (bjoern.luetjens@gmail.com)
2021-02-08 16:43:32

*Thread Reply:* There's wrappers that allow you to use your tensorflow code in pytorch. Something like (https://github.com/BlackHC/tfpyth). It's definitely more for prototyping than serious development, but might be worth a shot.

BlackHC/tfpyth
<p>Putting TensorFlow back in PyTorch, back in TensorFlow (differentiable TensorFlow PyTorch adapters).</p>
Stars
<p>537</p>
Language
<p>Python</p>
<a href="https://github.com/BlackHC/tfpyth">BlackHC/tfpyth</a>

Armin Bazarjani (bazarjan@usc.edu)
2021-01-15 15:51:29

Does anybody have any interesting/must read papers related to the long-tail distribution problem with CV that they would recommend reading? I’m trying to read up more on it but I want to make sure I’m not missing anything important.

Sara Beery (sbeery@caltech.edu)
2021-01-15 15:54:58

*Thread Reply:* A few good keywords: data imbalance/imbalanced data, few-shot learning, low data regime

🙌 Armin Bazarjani, Björn Lütjens
Sara Beery (sbeery@caltech.edu)
2021-01-15 15:56:27

*Thread Reply:* I really like this paper by Yin Cui: https://openaccess.thecvf.com/content_CVPR_2019/html/Cui_Class-Balanced_Loss_Based_on_Effective_Number_of_Samples_CVPR_2019_paper.html

👍 Armin Bazarjani
Armin Bazarjani (bazarjan@usc.edu)
2021-01-15 16:31:38

*Thread Reply:* Thanks! I'll be sure to read the paper.

John Payne (drjohnpayne@gmail.com)
2021-01-15 17:11:28

*Thread Reply:* Thanks for pointing out that paper @Sara Beery--looks very good. I’ve only skimmed it so far but it looks to me as if they are focused on single-label classification. Do you know if their method also works for multi-label classification, i.e., when you have more than one class in an image?

Sara Beery (sbeery@caltech.edu)
2021-01-15 17:26:18

*Thread Reply:* I think you could apply it in a multiclass scenario if you have localization, so each bounding box for example has one correct class. I haven't seen a direct multiclass version, but one may very well exist 🙂

The OpenCV Artificial Intelligence Kit (OAK) project began life as part of CommuteGuardian, a technological solution to the causes of many bicycle – automobile accidents, by alerting distracted drivers and warning cyclists just […]

Frederic (frederic@apic.ai)
2021-01-28 05:05:06

*Thread Reply:* I only got some experience with the kendryte k210 and was very impressed by its low power consumption and price.

30USD for display, camera and board.

I could not find any numbers but the OAK should be way more energy hungry (i might be wrong on this)

Armin Bazarjani (bazarjan@usc.edu)
2021-01-29 12:27:50

*Thread Reply:* That makes sense. So you would say in your experience the most important factor should be power consumption?

I haven’t heard about the k210, but it looks very good.

I also found the estimated specs on the OpenCV boards. 2.5W for the OAK-1 and 4W for the OAK-D. So, you’re definitely right in that they are far more power hungry than the 0.3W k210.

Tucker Lancaster (tlancaster6@gatech.edu)
2021-04-15 10:42:32

*Thread Reply:* Also consider an SSD instead of an HDD -- slightly more expensive, but faster and less likely to destroy your data if you drop it

Chloe Nouzille (cmnouzille@gmail.com)
2021-04-15 20:14:00

*Thread Reply:* Thank you both!

Gracie Ermi (gracieermiifthen@gmail.com)
2021-07-23 19:32:27

I've been building this list of conservation tech resources for folks who are interested in working in conservation tech or generally getting involved, and so far it's been a helpful thing to be able to share with folks. However, it's definitely not a comprehensive list, and I know many of you would have great stuff to add. So if you're interested, please feel free to suggest more organizations, educational resources, communities, open source projects, and anything else you think should be on here. And, feel free to share the list if you know of anyone who might find it to be helpful! https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/16RVh2J1cgmiMjCgIBoM9uU3ADXQXtdJ2GuLf1_ToHLI/edit?usp=sharing

❤️ Sara Beery, Lily Xu, Carly Batist, Ștefan Istrate, Matt McCann, Talia Speaker, Mitch Fennell, Hannah Yin

Jan Kees (jankees.schakel@sensingclues.org)
2021-07-24 08:56:50

great initiative ! Could you please add a few lines about our organisation as well?

organization: Sensing Clues Foundation

vol/tech-skills required: OpenEars / SERVAL open source sound recognition project)

CAIMAN open source cam-trap algorithms for recognising species and counting individuals > see kaggle iWildcam 2021, where we became photo-finish second

Conservation-tech: WITS turn-key open platform for nature conservation and wildlife protection: • Cluey Data Collector & Tracking app • Focus for Ops Rooms and google-like search across data sources • datahub (semantic triple store, geospatial, and doc-store, highly secure) • WildCAT for end-users (various apps) and for researchers (fully integrated Python, R, Jupyter Notebooks, Shiny, etc.) • CAIMAN (image recognition, see above) • SERVAL (sounds recognition, see above)

sensingclues.org
Sensing Clues
Wildlife Intelligence | Turn wild spaces into safe havens
Original URL: https://sensingclues.org
Sensing Clues
Wildlife Tool Suite
Meet the world's most innovative and complete nature conservation platform WILDLIFE TOOL SUITE

🎉 Sara Beery
Beckett Sterner (bsterne1@asu.edu)
2021-08-10 16:26:59

Curious to hear people's thoughts on how to avoid this sort of situation in AI for conservation? https://www.technologyreview.com/2021/07/30/1030329/machine-learning-ai-failed-covid-hospital-diagnosis-pandemic/

MIT Technology Review
Hundreds of AI tools have been built to catch covid. None of them helped.
Some have been used in hospitals, despite not being properly tested. But the pandemic could help make medical AI better.
Original URL: https://www.technologyreview.com/2021/07/30/1030329/machine-learning-ai-failed-covid-hospital-diagnosis-pandemic/
🙌 HM van Zyl
Sara Beery (sbeery@caltech.edu)
2021-08-10 16:28:23

Test in realistic scenarios, don't make unvalidated claims, build systems that allow end users to continually re-evaluate (ie quality control) to catch issues/model drift early on?

Jason Holmberg (Wild Me) (holmbergius@gmail.com)
2021-08-10 16:41:37

In a sense, this is an old problem with research. Academic researchers have few career incentives to share work or validate existing results. There's no reward for pushing through the last mile that takes tech from "lab bench to bedside," says Mateen.

💯 Stefan Schneider, Sara Beery, Gracie Ermi
Jason Holmberg (Wild Me) (holmbergius@gmail.com)
2021-08-10 16:41:57

This has been our experience as engineers adapting academic techniques.

Jason Holmberg (Wild Me) (holmbergius@gmail.com)
2021-08-10 16:42:23

We read the claims, but the devil is not only in the training data but also in the implementation and domain.

➕ Sara Beery, Emily Charry Tissier, Gracie Ermi
💯 Gullal S. Cheema, Ed Miller
👍 Jon Van Oast
Jason Holmberg (Wild Me) (holmbergius@gmail.com)
2021-08-10 16:43:27

And sometimes we don't even ask the right questions until we've applied the models several times to have the experience and context to understand.

🙌 Emily Charry Tissier, Sara Beery, Jon Van Oast, Howard L Frederick
Daniel Davila (daniel.davila@kitware.com)
2021-08-10 17:09:26

I wonder how many of these "hundreds of models developed" pretty much do the same thing, badly? That's a huge waste of human and financial capital. It seems like this was unavoidable wrt covid... We faced (face?) a large and immediate existential threat, which meant a LOT of financial motivation to abate the risk. I think it's understandable, if not expected, that people turned to a little understood technology with a consistent track record for misleading claims and just threw money at the wall hoping that we'd come up with a magic bullet. I feel that better coordination of efforts in general is a huge part of the solution. Open data standards, an expectation and insistence for peer review for public and environmental health models, and stronger coalitions of academic researchers, agencies, regulators, and industry professionals who can combine their resources instead of operating all independently in silos, all with different capabilities distributed across the TRL curve.

👍 Sara Beery, Jon Van Oast, Carly Batist, Ștefan Istrate, Talia Speaker
Sara Beery (sbeery@caltech.edu)
2021-08-10 17:11:03

*Thread Reply:* "I feel that better coordination of efforts in general is a huge part of the solution." 💯💯

In conservation, there are so many people spending hard won resources reinventing the wheel and running up against the same failure modes.

‼️ Carly Batist, Talia Speaker
Carly Batist (cbatist@gradcenter.cuny.edu)
2021-08-10 21:01:02

*Thread Reply:* ^retweet

Holger Klinck (hk829@cornell.edu)
2021-08-10 17:10:56

Amen!

Dan Sheldon (sheldon@cs.umass.edu)
2021-08-10 17:27:46

Ha, this excerpt from the article is mostly unsupported by the report it links to (the report discusses challenges but has an overall positive tone): > That’s the damning conclusion of multiple studies published in the last few months. In June, the Turing Institute, the UK’s national center for data science and AI, put out a report summing up discussions at a series of workshops it held in late 2020. The clear consensus was that AI tools had made little, if any, impact in the fight against covid. Though I suspect the main message of “AI didn’t help much” is well supported by other evidence.

Dan Sheldon (sheldon@cs.umass.edu)
2021-08-10 17:35:50

To support the point about the importance of coordination: for COVID forecasting, a big success story in my opinion has been the Covid 19 forecast hub (led by my friend Nick Reich at UMass). His group basically systematizes public health needs from the CDC into prospective forecasting competitions with clear rules. There are dozens of models submitted (including lots of “AI models”, many bad, some good, and one developed by me 😉 ); they are combined into an ensemble model and consumed by CDC. So, there’s some great coordination.

🙌 HM van Zyl, Sara Beery
👍 Bistra Dilkina, Lily Xu
HM van Zyl (senseivzyl@gmail.com)
2021-08-11 03:39:18

How useful AI is in facing covid is debatable, but the measurement infrastructure underlying it all is not.

How quickly we had working global analysis up and running, seemingly from backyard analysts, was amazing.

AI (and the hype behind it) did a ton of that behind the scenes.

Better co-ordination is a nice goal, but that requires people finding each other in a lot of noise. Something that doesn't happen by itself. In fact, we probably rely on AI to do a lot of that too.

I guess the real problem is in our marketing and how the media perceives us. We shouldn't let number of failed models be a metric for success for our industry in general.

To answer your question @Beckett Sterner, we don't. We stack the failures on top of each other until we get something good and hope the hype train gets us there.

Carly Batist (cbatist@gradcenter.cuny.edu)
2021-08-11 14:00:22

re: the coordination aspect, I think there have been a lot of initiatives aimed at just that, that have popped out recently. E.g., Wildlabs (AI for conservation), Climate Change AI (self-explanatory), ARIES (AI for env & sustinability), AI for the Planet, GoodAI (and it’s sub-communities), etc. I completely get the re-inventing the wheel, it definitely happens in conservation tech, where I mostly live. A lot is lacking and there is obviously much still to do. But just wanted to add some positive directions/projects to the conversation 🙂

👍 Sara Beery, Beckett Sterner, Emily Charry Tissier, HM van Zyl, Talia Speaker
Sara Beery (sbeery@caltech.edu)

HM van Zyl (senseivzyl@gmail.com)
2021-08-19 15:28:51

Hey all, as a corporate ML engineer, I have no real domain expertise, however @Emmanuel Dufourq and I are looking to do something impactful with Stellenbosch University. Perhaps some experts could give us an idea of something practical we could do.

Coming from a developing country, we really need to make a great case for funding, so it would be great if someone could share something that had real short term benefits. Thanks in advance, Henk

Carly Batist (cbatist@gradcenter.cuny.edu)
2021-08-19 15:33:56

Wireless sensor networks/meshing! ie PAM devices, camera traps, etc. save us ecologists from hours of trekking to pull SD cards and give us the (semi) realtime data!😂 I work in Madagascar with AudioMoth & Swift’s. The benefits would be huge, on top of the saved time, personnel, supplies (& therefore cost), more real-time info could be used to act on “alerts” like gunshots or chainsaws. And would facilitate rapid censusing on the ecology/conservation side as well.

Transmitting even summary type stats would be great, via LoRa or other IoT solutions. With embedded ML becoming more and more used, you could load a detection model and then have daily summaries or just the images or sound clips that passed the model to limit data transfer. Emmanuel & I for example have an ML model to pull out lemur calls from the Madagascar soundscape.

I should also say I have no idea what the feasibility of all this is as I’m a conservationist/ecologist by training!

Carly Batist (cbatist@gradcenter.cuny.edu)
2021-08-19 15:36:20

*Thread Reply:* Rainforest Connection has a system like this with their Guardian devices, but it’s not (to my knowledge) open. The devices aren’t ‘for-sale’ like Audiomoths, SongMeters, Swift’s. But they have a wireless data transfer system that sends gunshot alerts to rangers on the ground. You could talk to the folks over there about those tech logistics I suppose

Diego Marcos (diego.marcos.gonzalez@gmail.com)
2021-08-19 15:44:24

*Thread Reply:* And what about also few-shot learning for bio-acoustics to help identify rare species with few data samples?

Emmanuel Dufourq (edufourq@gmail.com)
2021-08-20 03:09:35

*Thread Reply:* I used to have real personal struggles with this as a phd student. I used to think that my work was not ever going to be as good as a theoretical paper and was boarder line going to give up on academia altogether because I was never going to be a LeCun or a Jürgen Schmidhuber. But turns out, application papers are super useful too!

❤️ Sara Beery, Jason Holmberg (Wild Me)

Ben Weinstein (benweinstein2010@gmail.com)
2021-08-19 18:45:52

@Hannah Kerner is here btw. If anyone wants to continue the conversation. Plus there is the machine meetup group on friday's that she and @Patrick Gray run. This week we are talking about very small object detection https://www.mdpi.com/2072-4292/12/15/2501

MDPI
YOLO-Fine: One-Stage Detector of Small Objects Under Various Backgrounds in Remote Sensing Images
Object detection from aerial and satellite remote sensing images has been an active research topic over the past decade. Thanks to the increase in computational resources and data availability, deep learning-based object detection methods have achieved numerous successes in computer vision, and more recently in remote sensing. However, the ability of current detectors to deal with (very) small objects still remains limited. In particular, the fast detection of small objects from a large observed scene is still an open question. In this work, we address this challenge and introduce an enhanced one-stage deep learning-based detection model, called You Only Look Once (YOLO)-fine, which is based on the structure of YOLOv3. Our detector is designed to be capable of detecting small objects with high accuracy and high speed, allowing further real-time applications within operational contexts. We also investigate its robustness to the appearance of new backgrounds in the validation set, thus tackling the issue of domain adaptation that is critical in remote sensing. Experimental studies that were conducted on both aerial and satellite benchmark datasets show some significant improvement of YOLO-fine as compared to other state-of-the art object detectors.
Original URL: https://www.mdpi.com/2072-4292/12/15/2501
👍 Sara Beery
Sara Beery (sbeery@caltech.edu)
2021-08-19 18:46:29

*Thread Reply:* Hi @Hannah Kerner and @Patrick Gray!!

👋 Hannah Kerner
Daniel Davila (daniel.davila@kitware.com)
2021-08-19 19:09:50

*Thread Reply:* This work looks really cool. We were recently looking into tiny object detection in WAMI imagery and one of the biggest issues with modern network design we found is the aggressive early downsampling that occurs for compute reasons. I have not seen a lot of work exploring this information bottleneck, which is critical when your targets are only 2-10 pixels wide. I feel like there is some paper waiting out there where spatial attention, maybe even a transformer, provides efficient information pathways for the full res input data to inform later semantically rich stages of the network, but I havent seen it yet.

Caleb Robinson (calebrob6@gmail.com)
2021-08-19 22:34:42

*Thread Reply:* @Daniel Davila have you seen HRNet? -- https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/research/blog/high-resolution-network-a-universal-neural-architecture-for-visual-recognition/

Microsoft Research
High-Resolution Network: A universal neural architecture for visual recognition - Microsoft Research
HRNet, created from general vision tasks, leads in many computer vision fields like semantic segmentation, human pose estimation, and object detection. Discover how HRNet achieves better results with fewer parameter and computation complexities.
Original URL: https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/research/blog/high-resolution-network-a-universal-neural-architecture-for-visual-recognition/
Caleb Robinson (calebrob6@gmail.com)
2021-08-19 22:39:03

*Thread Reply:* It maintains a high-resolution pathway through the network for this purpose (not highest resolution, but you could easily change it). There is a really good implementation in the pytorch-image-models library - https://github.com/rwightman/pytorch-image-models/blob/master/timm/models/hrnet.py.

timm/models/hrnet.py
<p>``` """ HRNet</p> <p>Copied from <a href="https://github.com/HRNet/HRNet-Image-Classification">https://github.com/HRNet/HRNet-Image-Classification</a></p> <p>Original header: Copyright (c) Microsoft Licensed under the MIT License. Written by Bin Xiao (<a href="mailto:Bin.Xiao@microsoft.com">Bin.Xiao@microsoft.com</a>) Modified by Ke Sun (<a href="mailto:sunk@mail.ustc.edu.cn">sunk@mail.ustc.edu.cn</a>) """ import logging from typing import List</p> <p>import torch import torch.nn as nn import torch.nn.functional as F</p> <p>from timm.data import IMAGENET<em>DEFAULT</em>MEAN, IMAGENET<em>DEFAULT</em>STD from .features import FeatureInfo from .helpers import build<em>model</em>with<em>cfg, default</em>cfg<em>for</em>features from .layers import create<em>classifier from .registry import register</em>model from .resnet import BasicBlock, Bottleneck # leveraging ResNet blocks w/ additional features like SE</p> <p><em>BN</em>MOMENTUM = 0.1 _logger = logging.getLogger(<strong>name</strong>)</p> <p>def <em>cfg(url='', <strong>**kwargs): return { 'url': url, 'num</em>classes': 1000, 'input<em>size': (3, 224, 224), 'pool</em>size': (7, 7), 'crop<em>pct': 0.875, 'interpolation': 'bilinear', 'mean': IMAGENET</em>DEFAULT<em>MEAN, 'std': IMAGENET</em>DEFAULT<em>STD, 'first</em>conv': 'conv1', 'classifier': 'classifier', <em></strong></em>kwargs }</p> <p>default<em>cfgs = { 'hrnet</em>w18<em>small': _cfg( url='<a href="https://github.com/rwightman/pytorch-image-models/releases/download/v0.1-hrnet/hrnet_w18_small_v1-f460c6bc.pth">https://github.com/rwightman/pytorch-image-models/releases/download/v0.1-hrnet/hrnet_w18_small_v1-f460c6bc.pth</a>'), 'hrnet</em>w18<em>small</em>v2': <em>cfg( url='<a href="https://github.com/rwightman/pytorch-image-models/releases/download/v0.1-hrnet/hrnet_w18_small_v2-4c50a8cb.pth">https://github.com/rwightman/pytorch-image-models/releases/download/v0.1-hrnet/hrnet_w18_small_v2-4c50a8cb.pth</a>'), 'hrnet</em>w18': <em>cfg( url='<a href="https://github.com/rwightman/pytorch-image-models/releases/download/v0.1-hrnet/hrnetv2_w18-8cb57bb9.pth">https://github.com/rwightman/pytorch-image-models/releases/download/v0.1-hrnet/hrnetv2_w18-8cb57bb9.pth</a>'), 'hrnet</em>w30': <em>cfg( url='<a href="https://github.com/rwightman/pytorch-image-models/releases/download/v0.1-hrnet/hrnetv2_w30-8d7f8dab.pth">https://github.com/rwightman/pytorch-image-models/releases/download/v0.1-hrnet/hrnetv2_w30-8d7f8dab.pth</a>'), 'hrnet</em>w32': <em>cfg( url='<a href="https://github.com/rwightman/pytorch-image-models/releases/download/v0.1-hrnet/hrnetv2_w32-90d8c5fb.pth">https://github.com/rwightman/pytorch-image-models/releases/download/v0.1-hrnet/hrnetv2_w32-90d8c5fb.pth</a>'), 'hrnet</em>w40': <em>cfg( url='<a href="https://github.com/rwightman/pytorch-image-models/releases/download/v0.1-hrnet/hrnetv2_w40-7cd397a4.pth">https://github.com/rwightman/pytorch-image-models/releases/download/v0.1-hrnet/hrnetv2_w40-7cd397a4.pth</a>'), 'hrnet</em>w44': <em>cfg( url='<a href="https://github.com/rwightman/pytorch-image-models/releases/download/v0.1-hrnet/hrnetv2_w44-c9ac8c18.pth">https://github.com/rwightman/pytorch-image-models/releases/download/v0.1-hrnet/hrnetv2_w44-c9ac8c18.pth</a>'), 'hrnet</em>w48': <em>cfg( url='<a href="https://github.com/rwightman/pytorch-image-models/releases/download/v0.1-hrnet/hrnetv2_w48-abd2e6ab.pth">https://github.com/rwightman/pytorch-image-models/releases/download/v0.1-hrnet/hrnetv2_w48-abd2e6ab.pth</a>'), 'hrnet</em>w64': _cfg( url='<a href="https://github.com/rwightman/pytorch-image-models/releases/download/v0.1-hrnet/hrnetv2_w64-b47cc881.pth">https://github.com/rwightman/pytorch-image-models/releases/download/v0.1-hrnet/hrnetv2_w64-b47cc881.pth</a>'), }</p> <p>cfg<em>cls = dict( hrnet</em>w18<em>small=dict( STEM</em>WIDTH=64, STAGE1=dict( NUM<em>MODULES=1, NUM</em>BRANCHES=1, BLOCK='BOTTLENECK', NUM<em>BLOCKS=(1,), NUM</em>CHANNELS=(32,), FUSE<em>METHOD='SUM', ), STAGE2=dict( NUM</em>MODULES=1, NUM<em>BRANCHES=2, BLOCK='BASIC', NUM</em>BLOCKS=(2, 2), NUM<em>CHANNELS=(16, 32), FUSE</em>METHOD='SUM' ), STAGE3=dict( NUM<em>MODULES=1, NUM</em>BRANCHES=3, BLOCK='BASIC', NUM<em>BLOCKS=(2, 2, 2), NUM</em>CHANNELS=(16, 32, 64), FUSE<em>METHOD='SUM' ), STAGE4=dict( NUM</em>MODULES=1, NUM<em>BRANCHES=4, BLOCK='BASIC', NUM</em>BLOCKS=(2, 2, 2, 2), NUM<em>CHANNELS=(16, 32, 64, 128), FUSE</em>METHOD='SUM', ), ),</p> <pre><code>hrnet_w18_small_v2=dict( STEM_WIDTH=64, STAGE1=dict( NUM_MODULES=1, NUM_BRANCHES=1, BLOCK='BOTTLENECK', NUM_CHANNELS=(40, 80), FUSE_METHOD='SUM' ), STAGE3=dict( NUM_MODULES=4, NUM_BRANCHES=3, BLOCK='BASIC', NUM_BLOCKS=(4, 4, 4), NUM_CHANNELS=(40, 80, 160), FUSE_METHOD='SUM' ), STAGE4=dict( NUM_MODULES=3, NUM_BRANCHES=4, BLOCK='BASIC', NUM_BLOCKS=(4, 4, 4, 4), NUM_CHANNELS=(40, 80, 1… </code></pre>
<a href="https://github.com/rwightman/pytorch-image-models">rwightman/pytorch-image-models</a>
Caleb Robinson (calebrob6@gmail.com)
2021-08-19 22:42:54

*Thread Reply:* It has been used to good effect in recent competition (e.g. winning solution in SpaceNet7) and has some good rankings in normal vision tasks (see paperswithcode). Actually one of the questions we discussed in the ML4RS reading group with the SpaceNet folks was "why do the winning solutions all upsample the imagery before putting it through their networks (e.g the winning solution upsamples 3x)?" I think the simple answer is because HRNet downsamples 4x and you need every pixel to distinguish building boundaries 😛

Caleb Robinson (calebrob6@gmail.com)
2021-08-19 22:49:56

*Thread Reply:* (You also might be interested in hard attention type approaches that don't "look" at the whole image https://proceedings.neurips.cc/paper/2019/file/8dd48d6a2e2cad213179a3992c0be53c-Paper.pdf)

Daniel Davila (daniel.davila@kitware.com)
2021-08-20 11:43:50

*Thread Reply:* Yep I sure have, thanks! As you point out, they also employ aggressive 4x early downsampling which you can either remove (which presents a practical problem for a lot of teams because you lose the benefit of imagenet pretraining unless you can swing that yourself) or upsample the input,. In both cases you take a large hit to runtime performance. Which becomes extra critical for real time or edge applications. I feel like there has to be a way to use context to attend to just very specific regions of in the input space at full resolution without shoving the entire full resolution image through the net

👍 Jason Holmberg (Wild Me), Siyu Yang, Caleb Robinson
Caleb Robinson (calebrob6@gmail.com)
2021-08-20 15:54:46

*Thread Reply:* I'm also very curious about this! Hard attention methods seem to be the relevant research thread here, although I haven't looked too much into them. I think the idea is: run some convs, decide on a subset of patches to look at based on the feature representation, run more convs on just those locations. The just makes these methods hard to train (as you can't backpropagate through selecting a subset) but you get to save in computation at inference time. This is the other paper I'm interested in -- https://arxiv.org/pdf/2102.10212.pdf

Sara Beery (sbeery@caltech.edu)
2021-08-20 15:59:51

*Thread Reply:* @Chris Yeh has work using an RL approach to do something that sounds similar, though it's less about reducing computational cost and more about reducing $$$ spent on high-res satellite data: https://scholar.google.com/citations?view_op=view_citation&hl=en&user=6Omq2pcAAAAJ&citation_for_view=6Omq2pcAAAAJ:qjMakFHDy7sC

👍 Caleb Robinson
Chris Yeh (chrisyeh96@gmail.com)
2021-08-20 16:24:42

*Thread Reply:* ^Newer version of the same RL idea for choosing when/where to zoom: https://arxiv.org/abs/2003.00425.

arXiv.org
Learning When and Where to Zoom with Deep Reinforcement Learning
While high resolution images contain semantically more useful information than their lower resolution counterparts, processing them is computationally more expensive, and in some applications,...
Original URL: https://arxiv.org/abs/2003.00425
🙌 Sara Beery, Caleb Robinson
Sara Beery (sbeery@caltech.edu)
2021-08-22 11:02:59

Interesting new dataset for self-supervised pretraining: https://openreview.net/forum?id=BwzYI-KaHdr. They made the choice to include no humans, which is an improvement over a lot of the ethics/privacy concerns in Imagenet.

OpenReview
PASS: An ImageNet replacement for self-supervised pretraining...
We introduce PASS, a large-scale image dataset that does not include any humans, and show that it can be used for high-quality model pretraning while significantly reducing privacy concerns.
Original URL: https://openreview.net/forum?id=BwzYI-KaHdr
😎 Jon Van Oast, David, HM van Zyl, Jason Holmberg (Wild Me), Sachith Seneviratne
Angjoo Kanazawa (kanazawa@berkeley.edu)
2021-10-31 20:22:50

Dear all, we are developing an unsupervised video motion segmentation method that learns a persistent appearance representation for the moving objects, and are wondering if you may have videos of animals that you would like to get a segmentation out of. It would be ideal if you tried running pre-trained methods like maskRCNN, but these don’t work due to out-of-domain generalization issues. If you have any collection of video we’d love to try our method and test it out! Please feel free to DM or email me (kanazawa@berkeley.edu). Thanks!

Jason Holmberg (Wild Me) (holmbergius@gmail.com)
2021-11-02 13:08:49

*Thread Reply:* Hi @Angjoo Kanazawa would YouTube videos be a good source of data? We built an Intelligent Agent to datamine YouTube videos for whale shark sightings, but after determining if the video was appropriate (a simple NLP-based binary classifier), we extracted keyframes (based on detected whale shark confidence scores) pre-individual ID. Automated segmentation might be really interesting to help automate and improve the accuracy of individual ID.

Frederic Fol Leymarie (ffl@dynaikon.com)
2021-11-16 12:27:23

Greetings; we have a UK-based R&D job opportunity for developing deep learning applications for biodiversity monitoring (animal focused). Specifics: Train NN models (based on the MMdetection framework) using the Amazon web services resources to detect animals from camera traps Join a small team developing exciting applications “at the edge” and “on the cloud” to better service biodiversity monitoring, with a focus on animal welfare, providing affordable solutions to citizen scientists and specialists, as well as governments, local councils, and other organisations. DynAikon is an R&D startup, developing IP, software and hardware. We have received funding from Innovate UK, Digital Catapult (Machine Intelligence Garage) and the EU (Horizon 2020). We are part of a current international consortium at the crossings of biodiversity monitoring and citizen science, with a focus on integrating AI and Machine Learning in the new services we develop. You will have access to this special network of international multi-disciplinary experts. More details: https://dynaikon.com/news/2021-11-12-job-listing/

🎉 Oisin Mac Aodha, Jason Holmberg (Wild Me), Carl Boettiger, Jason Parham, Daniel Grzenda, Riccardo de Lutio, Sara Beery, Dante Wasmuht
Jorrit van Gils (vangilsjorrit@gmail.com)
2021-12-01 08:06:40

Hi all, I have trained a pose estimation network DeepLabCut to predict animal poses (key point coordinates). The next step would be to use these key points to predict the type of behaviour (Foraging, moving or other). I already labelled the data with behaviour. Which network would be suitable to transfer key points into a behaviour classification? Anyone who did this before? Are there any examples available? Thank you! Jorrit

👍 Sara Beery, Jason Holmberg (Wild Me), Juan Arrechea, Dhruv Sheth
🦌 Stefan Schneider, Sara Beery
Daniel Davila (daniel.davila@kitware.com)
2021-12-01 09:56:19

*Thread Reply:* Ive been playing around with the ResGCN work recently, I had some success with few-shot AR on a limited dataset of human activities.

https://github.com/yfsong0709/ResGCNv1

yfsong0709/ResGCNv1
ResGCN: an efficient baseline for skeleton-based human action recognition.
Stars
87
Language
Python
Daniel Davila (daniel.davila@kitware.com)
2021-12-01 09:58:23

*Thread Reply:* With such a low dimensional signal (keypoints extracted from the relatively high-dimensional video input), you also shouldnt discount the power of simple heuristic-based approaches. For example, if the deer's legs are straight it's probably standing, right? Etc... can be powerful information when trying to constrain the space of possible activities under observation.

Jorrit van Gils (vangilsjorrit@gmail.com)
2021-12-01 11:28:40

*Thread Reply:* Great @Daniel Davila. I will take a look at your suggestion. Although used on humans it might also work for Red deer. In your research, did your output also contained a behaviour classification or something else?

Jorrit van Gils (vangilsjorrit@gmail.com)
2021-12-01 11:34:31

*Thread Reply:* @Daniel do you know any examples of these heuristic-based approaches? Do you mean not using a DL-model but instead a machine learning algorithm. Or do you mean neither of them?

Daniel Davila (daniel.davila@kitware.com)
2021-12-01 11:41:27

*Thread Reply:* Yeah so for heuristic approaches, you dont need an ML model at all necessarily. You can reason about the relative locations of joints, particularly if you have a world model (e.g. you know which directions are up and down). For example, in humans, if somebody has their arm raised straight above their head, there are very few actions they could be doing (relative to the 1000s of actions possible in an open world).

Daniel Davila (daniel.davila@kitware.com)
2021-12-01 11:42:02

*Thread Reply:* And yes, I was using resgcn to take in a pose graph and output an activity (running, sitting, etc...)

Jorrit van Gils (vangilsjorrit@gmail.com)
2021-12-01 12:50:04

*Thread Reply:* Sounds interesting Daniel. Good to keep in mind that other methods could also work. Very happy with your tips!

Daniel Davila (daniel.davila@kitware.com)
2021-12-01 20:45:39

*Thread Reply:* No problem! Good luck.

👍 Jorrit van Gils
Jan Kees (jankees.schakel@sensingclues.org)
2021-12-05 02:56:48

*Thread Reply:* very cool en useful development! @Jorrit van Gils, do you some more background information on your quest? Like, which types of behaviors do you distinguish, which one are expected to be very hard to distinguish from each other (where a sequence of images may help to improve the outcome)?

@John Beuving , maybe nice for you too, to have a look at

Jorrit van Gils (vangilsjorrit@gmail.com)
2021-12-08 08:40:39

*Thread Reply:* Hey @Jan Kees , thank you for the reply. As you can see I created three categories of behaviour ("Foraging", "Moving" and "Other") which I further divided into sub behaviours . Ideally you want to classify behaviour in detail and thus classify on the sub behaviours, however few images that most of these sub behaviour categories have makes it hard to properly train detecting these behaviours. Therefore I will first focus on classification of the 3 "main" behaviours that do have a fair amount of data and are more or less evenly distributed amongst the three groups.

Jan Kees (jankees.schakel@sensingclues.org)

Hello! I’m wondering if anyone is interested in talking to some elementary schoolers about yourself and your work? These students are learning how to code, and their teachers are looking to show them examples of real people who write code to tackle real world problems. You would only need to talk for 15-30 minutes (you can share as much or as little as you want!), and then the rest of the time can be for Q&A with the kids. When I talked to students at this school previously, they were extremely excited about the idea of building tech for wildlife, so I’m certain they would be very excited to hear from any of you! Here is a sign up sheet with dates, times and age groups for each session if you want to take a look! Let me know if you have any questions or want to talk though ideas for sharing your work with younger students! Charlotte (chalange@uos.de)
2022-01-13 11:47:07

Hello wonderful people!  I am currently co-lecturing a Deep Learning Course in which students have to hand in a final coding project. I want to motivate them to work on a project on nature/wildlife conservation (or climate science). For that purpose, I am setting up a list with resources: From open datasets and challenges, platforms and communities, publications to get inspired to tutorials and workshops. Please feel invited to add to or comment on the list! Also let me know if you happen to have some smaller-scale project on which you could let some motivated Bachelor/Master students go wild on 🙃

The list is accessible here: https://hackmd.io/@Sp2mwyxuRAOrWv8BhDJ7eg/deep-learning-for-nature

2022-02-10 07:29:28

Hello everyone, I am devis and write from EPFL, switzerland! I am new here, but i am looking forward to engage in super discussions!

👋 Diego Marcos, Kewal Shah, Riccardo de Lutio, Andrés C Rodríguez, Ben Koger, Sara Beery, Kakani Katija, Dhruv Sheth, Elijah Cole (Deactivated), Yihang She, Yves Bas, Catherine Villeneuve, Emmanuel Dufourq, Caleb Robinson, Dan Morris, Lily Xu, Jason Holmberg (Wild Me), Ben Weinstein, Maxime Vidal, Sachith Seneviratne, Vienna Saccomanno, Björn Lütjens, Lloyd Hughes, Jon Van Oast
Ben Weinstein (benweinstein2010@gmail.com)
2022-02-15 00:23:21

*Thread Reply:* By coincidence I was reading this tonight. Super interested in the variable length representations through max/avg pooling of the features before learning a representation to concat. We have multiple (and variable) years of HSI data for tree species prediction. I had tried averaging the softmax scores across years for the same location, but it is not better than just taking the most recent year. I'm going to explore this idea in Fig 3. Thanks!

Devis Tuia (devis.tuia@epfl.ch)
2022-02-15 02:54:22

*Thread Reply:* Hey Ben! happy to hear that you enjoyed reading the paper. Yes, in this case, depending on the aggregator you can explore from an average to a max to a learned combination.. back in the day I was working on clouds prediction on time series (using an RNN) and using a weighted combination ( with more weight on the most recent image) was working pretty well!

Devis Tuia (devis.tuia@epfl.ch)
2022-02-15 02:54:39

*Thread Reply:* https://arxiv.org/abs/2012.10393

arXiv.org
A deep network approach to multitemporal cloud detection
We present a deep learning model with temporal memory to detect clouds in image time series acquired by the Seviri imager mounted on the Meteosat Second Generation (MSG) satellite. The model...
Original URL: https://arxiv.org/abs/2012.10393
Devis Tuia (devis.tuia@epfl.ch)
2022-02-15 02:55:28

*Thread Reply:* Somehow for multi-year problems I feel the domain shift issue is to be solved first, unless you are using separate models per year

Sara Beery (sbeery@caltech.edu)
2022-04-18 12:31:18

Hey everyone! Looking for advice for a friend. She works at a conservation NGO and has a technical but not CS background, and is looking to take a sabbatical and do a data science bootcamp for 1-2 months. Not intended to help her get a CS job, but intended to enable her to depend less on CS and data science people in her current role at the NGO. I know very little about these bootcamps, but some seem a bit predatory. Does anyone have any experience or advice?

💕 Jon Van Oast, Lee Wall
👍 Talia Speaker, Dhruv Sheth
Daniel Davila (daniel.davila@kitware.com)
2022-04-18 12:49:58

*Thread Reply:* What kind of CS skills are we talking here? Like AI, general programming skills, data structures?

Sara Beery (sbeery@caltech.edu)
2022-04-18 12:53:58

*Thread Reply:* I think data exploration and visualization in R and/or python, and maybe some data mining and rudimentary AI

Lloyd Hughes (hughes.lloyd@gmail.com)
2022-04-18 13:16:17

*Thread Reply:* DataCamp offer some great online course, I know a few people who have done Data Science and Python courses through them and were pretty happy with it. If she is looking for in person courses then my recommendation would be to see if any university nearby is offering these over the summer (Quite often they have partner institutes which run private short courses for them - and thus they are normally of a higher quality).

👍 Sara Beery
Brian Lee (brianlee52@ucsb.edu)
2022-04-18 13:16:32

*Thread Reply:* Hi Sara, I know this isn’t exactly what your friend is looking for, but if she can take a bit longer off, UCSB’s Bren School offers a great 1-year masters in environmental data science that really emphasizes programming and data science for environmental professionals. Most of the students are exactly like your friend--environmental professionals who want a better understanding of these quantitative skills. https://bren.ucsb.edu/masters-programs/master-environmental-data-science

UCSB Bren School of Environmental Science &amp; Management
Master of Environmental Data Science
The Master of Environmental Data Science degree program (MEDS) at the Bren School is an 11-month professional degree program focused on using data science to advance solutions to environmental problems.
Original URL: https://bren.ucsb.edu/masters-programs/master-environmental-data-science
👍 Sara Beery, Carl Boettiger

2022-04-18 15:04:40

*Thread Reply:* A lot of universities are offering MOOCs on a revolving basis now, not just tied to academic calendar. These courses could be a good way to get your feet wet in a topic without getting scammed

👍 Sara Beery
Alex Brace (abrace@uchicago.edu)
2022-04-18 12:42:15

Hi Sara, I don't have experience with these boot camps, but I would be cautious about paying for this type of service. There are a ton of free (or cheap) resources for learning CS concepts. It may be worthwhile to look at some of the resources collected here to see if your friend would benefit from them: https://github.com/Developer-Y/cs-video-courses#introduction-to-computer-science

If they know anyone who can help explain specific concepts, that would be ideal!

Sara Beery (sbeery@caltech.edu)
2022-04-18 12:53:16

*Thread Reply:* I agree that there are a lot of resources available for free, but I also understand the interest in a guided learning experience with access to mentorship!

Alex Brace (abrace@uchicago.edu)
2022-04-18 13:08:40

*Thread Reply:* Yeah, the mentorship piece is very Important. Though, it might be a good idea to get their feet wet with basic Python or R before paying for instruction. I usually recommend the sentdex videos on youtube to students new to coding/Python. It seems to get our summer students up to speed quickly: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLQVvvaa0QuDeAams7fkdcwOGBpGdHpXln

Hope this helps! 🙂

YouTube
Learning to program with Python 3 (py 3.7)
Share your videos with friends, family, and the world
Original URL: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLQVvvaa0QuDeAams7fkdcwOGBpGdHpXln
Sara Beery (sbeery@caltech.edu)
2022-04-18 13:09:01

*Thread Reply:* This is great!! Thanks 🙂

Déva Sou (soudeva974@gmail.com)
2022-05-24 09:37:39

*Thread Reply:* Hi! I did an MSc. In Computational Biology in France. But for me it wasn't enough. During this MSc. I tried a Data Science Bootcamp (Le Wagon). That wasn't cheap at all but for me it worth the money. I needed a structure to launch myself into this adventure. Even if the resources are available for free on the internet, the expertise they provide and the support (intellectual and emotional) they give me were very helpful. It allowed me to integrate an internship in Deep Learning (that ends in July) for bird conservation and I hope to continue with a PhD in September. I hope this little testimony helped! 🙂

❤️ Sara Beery

Carly Batist (cbatist@gradcenter.cuny.edu)
2022-05-26 06:17:27

*Thread Reply:* The Conservation Tech Directory has some I believe - e.g., https://geonadir.com/. @Elizabeth Bondi also has the BIRDSAI dataset - https://lila.science/datasets/conservationdrones. And of course Sara already mentioned Ben - his AIDE project (https://github.com/Microsoft/aerial_wildlife_detection). And there’s another one I know of on LILA BC for seals - https://github.com/microsoft/arcticseals

conservationtech.directory
Conservation Tech Directory
Visit the post for more.
Original URL: https://conservationtech.directory/
GeoNadir
Home
GeoNadir's global drone mapping data repository supports scientists and environmental managers around the world to make data-driven decisions
Est. reading time
10 minutes
Original URL: https://geonadir.com/
LILA BC
Conservation Drones - LILA BC
Monitoring of protected areas to curb illegal activities like poaching is a monumental task. Real-time data acquisition has become easier with advances in unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) and sensors like TIR cameras, which allow surveillance at night when poaching typically occurs. However, it is still a challenge to accurately and quickly process large amounts of...
Written by
lilawp
Est. reading time
4 minutes
Original URL: https://lila.science/datasets/conservationdrones

Introduction to the model—ArcGIS pretrained models | Documentation

2022-06-01 10:09:00

Hi everyone! I’m currently looking for a bit of extra funding for my PhD research. Does anyone have any experience applying for Rufford Small Grants? If not would anyone have any recommendations for ‘small’ pots of money (£2,000-£6,000) for a super cool project on bird trade, technology and extinction? 🙏

👍 Monty Ammar, Reshu Bashyal
Stephanie O'Donnell (stephanie.odonnell@wildlabs.net)
2022-06-01 10:10:29

Stephanie O'Donnell (stephanie.odonnell@wildlabs.net)
2022-06-01 10:10:35

👋 Sicily Fiennes
Carly Batist (cbatist@gradcenter.cuny.edu)
2022-06-01 10:27:20

I’ve applied to Rufford before but have been unsuccessful haha. Other small conservation grants I know of: Society for Conservation Biology, American Philosophical Society’s Lewis & Clark Fund (if you’re doing fieldwork), Explorer’s club student grants.

And a lot of zoo ones, though idk how the pandemic has affected the availability of those. Sunset Zoo’s conservation scholar program, Columbus Zoo’s fund for conservation, John Ball Zoo’s wildlife conservation fund, Chicago Zoo’s CBOT endangered species fund, Phoenix Zoo’s conservation program, Oklahoma City Zoo’s conservation action now grants, Cleveland Zoo’s future for wildlife grants, Greenville Zoo’s conservation grants, Roger Williams Zoo’s Sophie Danforth conservation fund, Riverbanks Zoo’s Satch Krantz conservation fund, Fresno Chaffee Zoo’s wildlife conservation fund

Also, Cornell Lab of O has a directory of bird-specific conservation grants - https://www.birds.cornell.edu/landtrust/bird-focused-funding-opportunities/. Ornithology Exchange has a similar one - https://ornithologyexchange.org/funding/grants/.

Land Trust Bird Conservation Initiative
Funding Source Directory
Birds and bird conservation projects are great centerpieces around which to raise funds. From a biological perspective, birds can play important roles in planning and assessment by serving as indicator and umbrella species. Indicator species are good barometers of ecosystem condition; umbrella speci
Original URL: https://www.birds.cornell.edu/landtrust/bird-focused-funding-opportunities/
🙌 Stephanie O'Donnell, Vishakha Agrawal, Sicily Fiennes
Sicily Fiennes (sicilyfiennes@gmail.com)

Hi everyone,

I am currently looking for a potential mentor from a non-academic organization that focuses on animal movement research for my NSF INTERN fellowship application. I would like to know what are some non-academic organizations study animal movement (mainly quantitative research). Also, are there particular people I should consider reaching out to? I am a Ph.D. candidate from the John Fieberg and Allison Shaw labs at the U of Minnesota.

The only non-academic organization that I can think of so far that studies animal movement is WWF. Could anyone give me a list of NGOs and companies (+people) that study animal movement analysis?

Thanks!

Stephanie O'Donnell (stephanie.odonnell@wildlabs.net)
2022-06-15 04:06:20

*Thread Reply:* https://wildlabs.net/groups/drones

wildlabs.net
Drones | WILDLABS
Used to pick up signals from tracking gear on the ground, collect images of wildlife and habitats from the air, gather acoustic data with specialized hydrophones, or even collect snot samples from whales' blowholes, drones are capable of collecting high-resolution data quickly, noninvasively, and at relatively low cost.
Original URL: https://wildlabs.net/groups/drones
Daniel Davila (daniel.davila@kitware.com)
2022-06-15 23:17:44

*Thread Reply:* What kind of drone do you have? There are some pretty nice apps out there that allow you to set geofences, waypoints, and even detailed sequences like "fly here, point camera at this gps coordinate, take picture, move on..." most of the big players support these out of the box, and there are 3rd party apps (usually pretty cheap) that can exploit nicer payload navigation and control systems to fly all sorts of missions.

Emily Lines (erl27@cam.ac.uk)
2022-06-27 06:41:06

*Thread Reply:* Hi @Jinsu Elhance we have been using dronelink to fly dji systems and have found it to be very stable. Maybe it would suit you?

Ben Weinstein (benweinstein2010@gmail.com)
2022-06-27 12:05:25

does anyone have experience loading multi-dimensional arrays (more than 3 channels) into pytorch at scale? We got lots of GPUs, but have been using rasterio in our dataloaders and it scales very poorly. GPUs are often starved and waiting. Save as numpy .npy files? For training its not critical, but during prediction (10 to 100 million scale), we really need to focus on improved performance. Lots of solutions out there for 3 band data (https://developer.nvidia.com/dali). python's GIL seems to really limit rasterio performance, multiprocessing/thread provides no clear benefit. Dask?

NVIDIA Developer
DALI
NVIDIA Data Loading Library The NVIDIA Data Loading Library (DALI) is a portable, open source library for decoding and augmenting images,videos and speech to accelerate deep learning applications. DALI reduces latency and training time, mitigating bottlenecks, by overlapping training and pre-processing. It provides a drop-in replacement for built in data loaders and data iterators in popular deep learning frameworks for easy integration or retargeting to different frameworks. Training neural networks with images requires developers to first normalize those images.
Original URL: https://developer.nvidia.com/dali
Riccardo de Lutio (riccardo.delutio@geod.baug.ethz.ch)
2022-06-27 12:32:17

*Thread Reply:* Hi Ben, I imagine you are working with satellite images. In my experience saving them as into hdf5 datasets brought a nice performance gain especially when scaling up to larger applications. Might also be worth trying to evaluate which part of the data loading process is the bottleneck to try to optimise the implementation of the data loader itself.

Ben Weinstein (benweinstein2010@gmail.com)
2022-06-27 12:36:11

*Thread Reply:* thanks. the bottleneck is loading, its all been profiled. So you make a single h5 object and each step in the dataloader loads an image. Do you use multiple workers or load on the main thread?

Riccardo de Lutio (riccardo.delutio@geod.baug.ethz.ch)
2022-06-27 12:55:28

*Thread Reply:* In the case of Sentinel 2 you can for example save a h5 file for each tile/date combination, and that file can include a dataset of all the patches that you will want to extract from that tile so that will be of size: (#patches, height , width , #channels). Then you open that file the first time you want to access it (in the getitem() and not the init) such that you can use multiple workers and each has it’s own connection, also you need to make sure the h5file is closed when you delete the instance of the dataloader. I hope that helps!

Alex Brace (abrace@uchicago.edu)
2022-06-27 13:15:40

*Thread Reply:* Riccardo's solution has worked well for me in the past as well. I would also add that you can make use of data loader parameters such as memory pining, num_workers, and prefetch factor. Also, if your machine has many CPUs, it may benefit from limiting the number of threads that torch uses: https://pytorch.org/docs/stable/generated/torch.set_num_threads.html

Something reasonable like 4 workers with a prefetch of 4 usually works for me, but you can tune this.

Ben Weinstein (benweinstein2010@gmail.com)
2022-06-27 13:18:12

*Thread Reply:* thanks @Alex Brace, very familiar with this tools in other contexts, they provide no benefit in this case. @Riccardo de Lutio I'm interested in why you open it in the getitem and not the init. I see your point about the multiple workers. I would have thought that the cost of opening the .h5 would swamp that benefit. I'm going to try the same logic with rasterio. Thanks everyone for the feedback. I appreciate it.

Alex Brace (abrace@uchicago.edu)
2022-06-27 13:22:53

*Thread Reply:* The h5 needs to be opened in the getitem so each of the data worker threads can get their own handle. The init is run only by the main process I believe. I normally implement this by setting a boolean member variable in the init is_open=False . Then in the destructor you can have something like if self.is_open: self.h5_file.close()

This way you only open the h5 file once in the getitem e.g. if not self.is_open: self.h5_file = h5py.File(data_path, "r")

Riccardo de Lutio (riccardo.delutio@geod.baug.ethz.ch)
2022-06-27 13:24:32

*Thread Reply:* Yes exactly, same here.

Alex Brace (abrace@uchicago.edu)
2022-06-27 13:27:20

*Thread Reply:* Also if you happen to be on a cluster that supports an efficient node local temp storage option, then you can get additional benefit by copying your h5 file to the tmp space and passing the node local path to your data loader. This will minimize file system I/O. You could do this in your main function for instance (it is essentially an efficient cache you can use while your job runs).

h5 also supports seamless compression and nice chunking features that you may be able to make use of. I don't know the specific details of your dataset/application but it's something you may consider if the dataset is very large.

👍 Ben Weinstein
Caleb Robinson (calebrob6@gmail.com)
2022-06-27 13:59:17

*Thread Reply:* Hey Ben, do you have the code you are using anywhere? Simply reading GeoTIFF files with rasterio is usually quite fast for us

Caleb Robinson (calebrob6@gmail.com)
2022-06-27 14:00:18

*Thread Reply:* You can get large slowdowns if you are doing any reprojection steps with the data using rasterio, or trying to do windowed reading with a non-tiled GeoTIFF

Ben Weinstein (benweinstein2010@gmail.com)
2022-06-27 14:05:32

*Thread Reply:* here is the dataloader that reads .tif files from disk using rasterio. https://github.com/weecology/DeepTreeAttention/blob/1b704c74752c710bc03d0728f847be902f915d05/src/data.py#L240

<https://github.com/weecology/DeepTreeAttention/blob/1b704c74752c710bc03d0728f847be902f915d05/src/data.py | data.py>
<pre><code>class TreeDataset(Dataset): </code></pre>

2022-06-27 14:07:17

Ben Weinstein (benweinstein2010@gmail.com)
2022-06-27 14:09:14

*Thread Reply:* atleast according the snakeviz and cProfile.

Caleb Robinson (calebrob6@gmail.com)
2022-06-27 14:12:25

*Thread Reply:* is it easy to post a link to one of the image tiffs?

Ben Weinstein (benweinstein2010@gmail.com)
2022-06-27 14:12:59

*Thread Reply:* very small, often 10x10x369

Ben Weinstein (benweinstein2010@gmail.com)
2022-06-27 14:14:51

*Thread Reply:* increasing num_workers > 0 makes things much slower. The only solution I have found is to preload everything to memory. That works during train/test, but during prediction we are talking about 10> TB. So i've developed an on-the-fly cropper to cut out the crops (tree crowns) and predict them. There are some other complications, but that's the crux of it.

Ben Weinstein (benweinstein2010@gmail.com)
2022-06-27 14:15:19

*Thread Reply:* GPU utilization is under 5%.

Ben Weinstein (benweinstein2010@gmail.com)
2022-06-27 14:16:08

*Thread Reply:* thanks @Alex Brace, i'm definitely going to try the local storage idea. IO seems to be the crux.

Caleb Robinson (calebrob6@gmail.com)
2022-06-27 14:24:22

*Thread Reply:* just as a sanity check, I'm seeing that file is all 0's, is that suppossed to be the case?

Caleb Robinson (calebrob6@gmail.com)
2022-06-27 14:28:42

*Thread Reply:* As this data isn't georeferenced, and you don't need a dataset object that does windowed reading at all, you could try to use the tifffile package -- it calls into libtiff instead of libgdal and I've seen it is generally faster for this use case

Ben Weinstein (benweinstein2010@gmail.com)
2022-06-27 14:58:16

*Thread Reply:* sorry, that was a coincidence, its actually a multi-temporal model, and if there isn't any data for that year it gets padded with 0's (currently working on not reading the padded data). I'll have a go at tiffle and all these suggestions, thanks.

Daniel Davila (daniel.davila@kitware.com)
2022-06-27 16:32:32

*Thread Reply:* Im not sure how fast it is, but if you are loading large cubes just to throw some channels away a change of format may help. I used this package called spectral (https://pypi.org/project/spectral/) to work with large hyperspectral imagery in the past. Might be what you're looking for. I liked it because it let me load just the channels I wanted from the data cube for supported formats

Daniel Davila (daniel.davila@kitware.com)
2022-06-27 16:43:55

*Thread Reply:* Also, if loading larger samples, are you checking the simple stuff like that your dataloader isnt maxing out your system memory and dipping int swap or anything?

👍 Ben Weinstein
Daniel Davila (daniel.davila@kitware.com)
2022-06-27 16:52:04

*Thread Reply:* If you are spatially cropping a lot of individual images, COG comes to mind as well (https://medium.com/spatial-data-science/cloud-optimized-geotiff-cog-with-python-8e0a22b884c5) . We have implemented workflows that preprocesses all our source imagery into COG first, then we can rapidly sample sub regions across many large images quickly (like sticking together a big video tubelet from an ROI across time)

🎉 Ben Weinstein
Daniel Davila (daniel.davila@kitware.com)
2022-06-27 16:52:40

*Thread Reply:* If you cache this cog preproc, you can reuse each training/inference run so you dont have to recompute each time

Daniel Davila (daniel.davila@kitware.com)
2022-06-27 16:56:34

*Thread Reply:* @Jonathan Crall has a package that makes this pretty nifty, if it helps https://pypi.org/project/ndsampler/

PyPI
ndsampler
Fast sampling from large images
Original URL: https://pypi.org/project/ndsampler/
Ben Weinstein (benweinstein2010@gmail.com)
2022-06-29 14:24:16

*Thread Reply:* I don't know if its useful, but if anyone ever comes back to this thread, I found a couple improvements. 1) using the scratch space for large rasters is useful, but not huge, 2) For reasons that are still unclear (see https://github.com/microsoft/torchgeo/discussions/594, https://github.com/rasterio/rasterio/issues/2053), keeping rasterio objects open blocks mulit-processing for pytorch's dataloader. While it feels counter-intuitive, opening and closing the handle in the getitem is the key. This allows you to bring the needed CPU resources to bare.

<https://github.com/microsoft/torchgeo/discussions/594|#594 Custom Sampler - Unknown Exception>
<a href="https://github.com/microsoft/torchgeo">microsoft/torchgeo</a>
<https://github.com/rasterio/rasterio/issues/2053|#2053 IReadBlock error while multiprocessing>
<a href="https://github.com/rasterio/rasterio">rasterio/rasterio</a>
Caleb Robinson (calebrob6@gmail.com)
2022-06-29 14:50:17

*Thread Reply:* Thanks Ben, I don't think we've tried that in torchgeo, will have to see what happens there

William MacAskill is an Associate Professor in Philosophy and Research Fellow at the Global Priorities Institute, University of Oxford. He is one of the primary voices in a philanthropic movement known as “effective altruism” and the co-founder of three non-profits based on effective altruist principles: Giving What We Can, 80,000 Hours, and the Centre for Effective Altruism. He is also the Director of the Forethought Foundation for Global Priorities Research and the author of .

They discuss the &amp;#8220;effective altruism&amp;#8221; movement, choosing causes to support, the apparent tension between wealth and altruism, how best to think about generosity over the course of one&amp;#8217;s lifetime, and other topics. Sunnie S. Y. Kim (sunniesuhyoung@princeton.edu)
2022-07-13 10:37:07

Do you use Merlin? 🐦

Our research team (Sunnie Kim, Elizabeth Watkins, , Ruth Fong, Andrés Monroy-Hernández) is conducting research on understanding explainability needs of users of real-world computer vision applications, and how existing explainable AI (XAI) methods satisfy or not satisfy the identified needs. We're looking to interview users of the Merlin Bird ID application who regularly use Photo ID or Sound ID. If you are interested in chatting with us for about an hour over zoom, please fill out this short google form. Study participants will be compensated with a $30 gift card or a $30 donation to a bird conservation organization. Thanks and happy to answer questions via DM/email!

👀 Stephanie O'Donnell

Ben Weinstein (benweinstein2010@gmail.com)
2022-07-14 17:13:40

Does anyone have an opinion on whether we can use the same holdout dataset to evaluate AND calibrate the model? I'm working from https://arxiv.org/pdf/1904.01685.pdf and they are vague on if we need a third dataset (train/test/calibrate) to assess temperature. Sure, having more holdout data is always awesome, but given that almost never happens (most projects barely have enough test data), what bias is introduced by calibrating on the test dataset? My tree species model is typically overconfident.

Devis Tuia (devis.tuia@epfl.ch)
2022-07-15 01:38:36

*Thread Reply:* I always try to have one and also th ecomposition of the test set is super important to avoid data leakages (but oyu know that better than me). In stat, when sample size is small, people sometimes train models with one test sample out and predict it, then train another for another test sample, etc. It’s a bit insane computationally but…

👍 Ben Weinstein
Devis Tuia (devis.tuia@epfl.ch)
2022-07-15 01:41:16

*Thread Reply:* For aerial images, I always try to have the sets geographically disconencted, to avoid spatial biases of structures seen in train leaking in test (which would happen for example if you sample your test samples randomly from the images you have. Also, normalisation strategies induce biases if you normalise on the whole data (so you use the stat of the test set to normalise). In EO it changes results massively (= lower results, but honest) to split/normalise right.

🙌 Sean P. Rogers
Brad Pickens (bradley_pickens@fws.gov)
2022-09-23 09:24:33

*Thread Reply:* ...Picking up this older discussion, as it looks important! My philosophy on this is that we should always do our best to replicate the expected application during testing. Seems to me that calibration could be done on the training data...I'm curious about thoughts on this?? Here's an example of data leakage- what happens when a random split of objects is used for training/test splits compared to when parent images (i.e., not just objects) are separated for training/test splits.

Jason Holmberg (Wild Me) (holmbergius@gmail.com)
2022-08-06 22:07:20

Many orgs don't start off with enough funding for full salaries but instead need contract labor to get initial projects off the ground, which is Wild Me's experience when we started. I am just passing along a recommendation in case any of your teams need contract work for Python or DevOps. Wild Me just finished a two-year contracting engagement with Mulich LLC, which is really two experienced software professionals (Michael Mulich and Karen Chan). They were embedded with the team and are clearly very experienced Python hands. They handled the high complexity of our platforms with ease, including suggesting good designs and debugging complex and thorny issues. We will continue to work with them on future projects, but they're a very good resource if you need skilled Python or DevOps help but don't have a full position funded. They primarily work with nonprofits. They are not AI experts but rather can help build the scaffolding around AI-focused projects. Michael is the primary contact: michael.mulich@gmail.com

I am posting this with their permission, and I am independent and have no business interest in their work.

❤️ Suzanne Stathatos, Lily Xu, nyakundi lamech, Rita Pucci, Stephanie O'Donnell, Ted Schmitt, Marconi Campos, Amrita Gupta, Chris Lang

Dan Morris (agentmorris@gmail.com)
2022-08-10 19:27:38

I have a question that I think will at least entertain this community, but is sufficiently unanswerable that it definitely belongs in the "random" channel... how many ecologists are there? Like in the world? I mean that exactly as literally as it sounds. Have at it.

🦆 Jon Van Oast, Sara Beery, Alexander Robillard, Elijah Cole (Deactivated), Kasirat
Carly Batist (cbatist@gradcenter.cuny.edu)
2022-08-10 21:15:38

*Thread Reply:* ESA has ~9000 members, but that’s obviously a minimum considering there are many more that are not members. I guess it depends on what you define as an ecologist - people may also identify as environmental scientists, wildlife biologists, etc. The US Bureau of Labor Statistics has categories for environmental specialists (87,000), wildlife biologists (19,000), and conservation scientists (39,000), and across those 3, there are >130,000 jobs per the 2020 data, though not everyone within those categories is likely to be doing ecology by the strict definition of the word.

🙌 Carl Boettiger, Sara Beery
Dan Morris (agentmorris@gmail.com)
2022-08-10 22:02:13

*Thread Reply:* Oooh, those are good numbers. I'll take that as a rough count for various definitions within the US; I wonder if we have any way to anecdotally extrapolate that? Even for this semi-arbitrary exercise, scaling based on population seems dicey. Is there any conference, for example, that we for some reason believe has geographically proportional participation that we could use to extrapolate those US numbers? Or maybe somewhere there's an estimate of the number of degree-granting programs in various departments by country.

Lukas Picek (lukaspicek@gmail.com)
2022-08-17 10:15:51

Hi there, is anyone attending ECCB (European Congress of Conservation Biology) next week?

Carly Batist (cbatist@gradcenter.cuny.edu)
2022-08-29 17:00:59

We (@Gracie Ermi & I) just passed the 1-year anniversary of the Conservation Tech Directory launch! And published a new update to commemorate, if you’d like to check it out: https://conservationtech.directory/. While you’re there, you can subscribe to our listserv on the site, to hear about future updates & get these snazzy emails every other month.😊

Thanks especially to the many of you who have contributed resources yourselves over the year as well - we so appreciate it! 🤩

Figshare: https://doi.org/10.6084/m9.figshare.15442200.v15 Form to add new resources: https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLScfbapq1sQdVWzEGVR1ezR2_TkKEDcV9Bcp-3idV6ZmmJxpHw/viewform

👍 Rowan Converse, Jason Holmberg (Wild Me), Casey Youngflesh, Lily Xu, Andy Viet Huynh, Benjamin Kellenberger, Dan Morris, Emily Charry Tissier, Ted Schmitt, Timm Haucke, charlotte, Marconi Campos
🥂 Jon Van Oast, Jason Holmberg (Wild Me), Lily Xu, Andy Viet Huynh, Elijah Cole (Deactivated), Marconi Campos
