Lily Xu (lily_xu@g.harvard.edu)
2022-08-29 21:25:02

*Thread Reply:* this is a fantastic service, i've recommended so many students here who want to get into AI for conservation!!! thank you Gracie and Carly :)

😍 Carly Batist, Gracie Ermi
Levi Cai (lcai@whoi.edu)
2022-09-03 22:02:39

Out of curiosity, for those who collect video/lots of digital data in the field, what data storage/management devices/software/systems do folks use or suggest (or have any kind of advice)?

We currently generate about 5TB of data per trip (~2wks) collected across many devices (robots, GoPros, etc., maybe 500GB per device per day), but are likely going to scale up (~5x) pretty easily, in areas with very limited internet and rough roads. We currently travel around with a Synology NAS/RAID setup and do a very annoying data xfer of each device onto it at the end of each day (crazy mess of ethernet cables, routers/switches, laptops, devices, etc.). The alternative solutions has been 1/2TB NVME drives, but even that has many pain points. Thanks so much in advance!

👀 Carl Boettiger, Chuck Xia
Frederic (frederic@apic.ai)
2022-09-07 07:53:18

*Thread Reply:* Hi @Levi Cai, the last three years I collected and analysed beyond 100TB of videos (multiple years of footage) each year and had the need to store them for processing, occasional randomly access and archive them.

I used cloud providers (spending a lot of $) and hosting everything on premiss in our office.

I tried to describe our setups a bit, but there is so much that this is incomplete and might look chaotic. we can have a call if you would like to have more insights or we can organize a small support group if more are interested.

In generally, I try it try to think of different tiers of storage (similar to the cloud providers) and replicated the same locally: • deep archive (accessed << 1 per year and in batches) • archive (accessed a few times per year) • processing (fast access with low latency) Each study is only in one of these steps and therefore i can schedule data transfers accordingly

But your approach may be different, depending on your use case.

In the cloud (e.g. AWS): • Get a snowball / snowcone from AWS for uploading the data or access to the backbone of the university (100Gbit/s). • S3 storage (One Zone-Infrequent Access) for holding the data while its processed. (directly upload to the class to save money. • EBS storage for processing (copy a folder, bucket that should be analysed to it). • S3 Glacier / Deep glacier for archive. OnPrem: • USB 3.0 SSD to collect the data (I got ~100 PNY Elite USB 3.0 Portable) -> Main idea is to ignore transfere times to the server by having enough on hand to alway get a fresh SSD • NAS with ZFS pool with a lot of spinning disks and IO bandwith for holding the data while its processed or not ready for archiving (it’s faster than an ssd [throughput], but has a greater latency than an ssd). • NAS with ZFS pool with a few disk, great deal of redundancy and lot of storage. Archiving (disk are mostly turned of / idle state, since they are no access) • NVME and Ram disk holding a few jobs worth of data from the NAS for processing and low latency access on a workstation. • Workstations and NAS are connected via 10G ethernet and proper switches. • Lastly (we are not using it) tape drive for real archiving. Regarding hardware choices for our DIY approach: • Modern mainboard (10G ethernet), cpu, a good amount of ram. • multiple JBODs enclosures from ebay (just a bunch of drives) • PCIE SAS / fiber controler card to interface with the JBODs • PCIE USB cards, such that you can attach a lot of external storage for transfere • True NAS scale as OS • a couple of SSDs (nvme) as caches. => Since cost is always factor, the server cost me about 500 Euro (mainboard, cpu, ..), 200 Euro per 15 hdd slots (JBOD, …) and then your HDD price.

Painfull learnings: • Mailing your data to AWS (snowcone) might be faster than uploading them. • If you want to utilize a 10G or 100G uplink, make sure your hardware can handle it. • Proper cooling for the HDDs, they dont like heat. • Never store single images on a HDD, accessing them becomes a pain when you want to access all of them. Ingesting them as .tar in batches helps. • Be really care full, if you do not have a backup with rm. Having a lot of data might result in not being able to afford a backup. • Depending on the size of your zfs pool, you might need to buy 5 additional 16TB drives if you want to expand it (costing you 1.500) size your pools wisely (e.g. small for archive (big hdd), large for processing (small hdd). • Have a good system for labeling, tracing and checking external storage media (know where it is, its orgin, next step and their checksum). Loosing or not knowing the origin of data is bad 🙈 Regarding the mess of switches, … I bought a server cabinet of the second hand market for 50 Euro and put everything in there. Event the data ingestion stage, so only it is messy. Additionally i have a small shelf for external HDD, … that i used in the past.

Frederic (frederic@apic.ai)
2022-09-07 07:58:22

*Thread Reply:* In general we stopped to transfer anything on the field, since we always did mistakes on the field an stuff gets lost. We just replaced recording storage devices and focuses more on how to process the huge amount of data

Frederic (frederic@apic.ai)
2022-09-07 09:12:23

*Thread Reply:* Since this is #random AWS snowballs are quite unique and interesting. Here is a picture from a field trip 🙂 Sadly you still need a lot of power for them 🙈

Levi Cai (lcai@whoi.edu)
2022-09-08 11:40:05

*Thread Reply:* Wow thanks so much for the sharing!! I’ll read through everything before asking more details.

Levi Cai (lcai@whoi.edu)
2022-09-08 11:40:56

*Thread Reply:* In general we follow vaguely similar philosophies and setup, but you seem much more organized about each portion.

Carl Boettiger (cboettig@berkeley.edu)
2022-09-28 00:42:08

*Thread Reply:* Late to the party — for on prem, did you consider something like a minio setup over the zfs pool?

Howard L Frederick (simbamangu@gmail.com)
2022-11-03 04:05:28

*Thread Reply:* @Frederic thank you, that’s a good summary of the hardware and data management considerations - curious about the wattage required for the setup you have (we have ‘in the field’ considerations too).

Frederic (frederic@apic.ai)
2022-11-03 09:11:51

*Thread Reply:* @Howard L Frederick sadly I can not give you any numbers on the wattage user by the setup. In only measure our entire server cabinets (incl. GPUs, …). The share of the NAS is probably 200 - 450 watt under load, but i have not measured it (Ryzen based NAS, 2x JBOD with 15 HDDs each).

I know that you can bring it down with a lot of optimisations to ridiculously low numbers in IDLE, but out of the box it will draw a lot. If you want to reduce the energy used, buying second hand might not be the best option.

I want to reduce the energy consumption on my home NAS and got across this useful video for optimisation: https://youtu.be/MucGkPUMjNo

AI Forum
AI for the Environment - AI Forum
The AI Forum Te Kāhui Atamai Iahiko o Aotearoa is researching the potential for Artificial Intelligence (AI) to contribute to environmental outcomes for Aotearoa New Zealand.  This research project is funded by Stats NZ Tatauranga Aotearoa and the Ministry for the Environment Manatū Mō Te Taiao. The report will describe how AI can be used … Continue reading "AI for the Environment"
Est. reading time
2 minutes
Original URL: https://aiforum.org.nz/reports/ai-for-the-environment/
Eco-index
Artificial Intelligence Tools — Eco-index
We are applying artificial intelligence tools to high resolution satellite and aerial imagery to understand biodiversity state and trends. We are actively investing in this area to create and train algorithms that are cost and time efficient + produce reliable results. These tools will be open sourc
Original URL: https://eco-index.nz/artificial-intelligence-tools

2022-09-29 20:47:49

Not sure if this is too far off tangent from the group's focus, but is there potential to use SD finetuned end-to-end as a source of data augmentation in some of the cool models/datasets I'm seeing on this slack? Attached couple of images for the prompt "A close up painting of Sachith riding a dragon", theoretically it should be possible to explore as a data augmentation strategy for rare species perhaps? This is finetuned end to end on 5 images of myself on an A100. Throughput is about 20k images per week on a P100, on an A100 it's about 120k per week or so. Apologies if this is silly. I mostly use this for urban design/computer vision work, but thought it may be of interest.

🙌 Malika Nisal Ratnayake, Andrew Schulz, Josh Seltzer, Jaanak, Rita Pucci
Sachith Seneviratne (sachith.seneviratne@unimelb.edu.au)

Abhay (abhaykash12@gmail.com)
2022-10-01 21:47:37

*Thread Reply:* Not sure what to make of this outside of it being creepily hilarious but here's a quick example where I masked out the head and ran inpainting. I'm no vision expert so I'll leave the causal factors to the ones who understand this better but I presume, with scaled fine tuning on camera trap images, this will likely get significantly better

👍 Sachith Seneviratne, Catherine Villeneuve, Sara Beery
Abhay (abhaykash12@gmail.com)
2022-10-01 21:49:57

*Thread Reply:* Heres another one - I've added the mask this time for clarity

👍 Sachith Seneviratne, Moira Shooter
Sachith Seneviratne (sachith.seneviratne@unimelb.edu.au)
2022-10-01 21:55:09

*Thread Reply:* Cool, what's the species on the left (and the right)?

Abhay (abhaykash12@gmail.com)
2022-10-01 22:00:16

*Thread Reply:* I presume, bobcat on the left and I prompted bobcat for the right (my initial prompt, had "bob cat" and it inpainted a domestic cat). Given the underlying nature of the training set, it's likely to have a heavy bias towards domestic creatures.

Sachith Seneviratne (sachith.seneviratne@unimelb.edu.au)
2022-10-01 22:17:25

*Thread Reply:* ah ok, did you do a negative prompt

Sachith Seneviratne (sachith.seneviratne@unimelb.edu.au)
2022-10-02 01:36:11

*Thread Reply:* These birds are really funny haha, I think the model is making some mistakes with this one for example: (Oh I can only upload 10 at a time)

Beckett Sterner (bsterne1@asu.edu)
2022-10-04 14:41:26

*Thread Reply:* Keep in mind that birds + mammals are < 20,000 species, while there are millions of insects and many animal species are nearly morphologically indistinguishable or too small to photograph reliably with camera traps. AI won't "solve" curation for species recognition without sustained investment in the research and enthusiast communities that generate the quality data it relies on. Make sure this research on synthetic data generation doesn't perpetuate the devaluation of detailed, long-term study of organisms and species in biology.

❤️ Sara Beery, Abhay, Sachith Seneviratne, Ted Schmitt
Sachith Seneviratne (sachith.seneviratne@unimelb.edu.au)
2022-10-04 16:46:58

*Thread Reply:* Definitely, I think that's a real risk with synthetic data approaches. Real data is always more valuable than synthetic data. The problem I'm trying to solve is how to effectively teach the model about data we already have. This can help solve partially solved problems better. For solving new problems you need new data. As Sara pointed out, the model is not universal, so I'm interested in pointing it towards more specialized or generalized knowledge.

Sachith Seneviratne (sachith.seneviratne@unimelb.edu.au)
2022-10-05 19:38:29

*Thread Reply:* @Abhay This looks more promising than make a video (at least qualitatively): https://imagen.research.google/video

Imagen Video: High Definition Video Generation with Diffusion Models
Imagen Video
High Definition Video Generation with Diffusion Models
Original URL: https://imagen.research.google/video
👀 Abhay, Moira Shooter
Ben Weinstein (benweinstein2010@gmail.com)
2022-10-18 19:59:33

Here is a completely random project thought. We often get developers from industry, so I think this might be a good fit. I would love, and think there would be a large market for, a 'dawn chorus app' that uses audio from the Macaulay library/xeno canto and ebird checklists to generate synthetic 10 minute snippets of bird song from a given location around the world. Fun little details like making the audio scene using generative/adversarial neural networks and the abundance distribution from checklists to make it sound real. How often the most common birds sing, etc. https://arxiv.org/pdf/2201.02490.pdf. I am preparing for a trip to Magdalena Colombia and I would love to hear sounds from the sites i'll be visiting. @Dan Morris and @gvanhorn what do you think?

😎 Jon Van Oast, Armi Tiihonen, Sara Beery, Alexander Robillard, Yseult Hb, Kai Waddington, Clare Price
🎶 Dan Morris
💡 Chinmay Talegaonkar
Dan Morris (agentmorris@gmail.com)
2022-10-18 21:59:46

*Thread Reply:* I could have sworn that OpenSoundscape:

https://github.com/kitzeslab/opensoundscape

...included a bunch of stuff on realistic soundscape synthesis, albeit for the purpose of training models, not for the purpose of the soundscapes themselves. I can see no evidence of this in the README of the repo, so either (a) I hallucinated that entire conversation with Justin ~4 years ago, (b) that was true at some point, or (c) Justin's lab has a different project about soundscape synthesis.

Sara Beery (sbeery@caltech.edu)
2022-10-19 09:09:14

*Thread Reply:* I would totally use this if it existed

Justin Kitzes (justin.kitzes@pitt.edu)
2022-10-19 10:44:29

*Thread Reply:* Someone forwarded this thread to me, so I hopped in to confirm that Dan is not losing his mind, and in fact his memory is shockingly good 😄. So yes for a while we were using Brian McFee's scaper package to synthesize soundscapes for the purposes of training (and just for fun). Eventually (and currently in OpSo) we do something much simpler that's not highlighted in the docs because it's more of a practice than a functionality - when we do training we just take whatever "clean" calls we want (usually Xeno Canto, Macaulay would work fine too) and overlay them on fully annotate soundscapes that we know don't otherwise contain the species - we use these background soundscapes as negatives also. Seems to work well for our purposes.

😂 Sara Beery
Justin Kitzes (justin.kitzes@pitt.edu)
2022-10-19 10:44:57

*Thread Reply:* OpSo does have the functionality/wrappers to do those overlays pretty easily along with other augmentation.

Justin Kitzes (justin.kitzes@pitt.edu)
2022-10-19 10:45:57

*Thread Reply:* Ben's question is much more complex though and I think this is the bigger question if you really wanted a realistic soundscape, which is about the number of individuals of each species, duration of singing bouts, and temporal autocorrelation in songs/bouts - I think that's all pretty poorly understood quantitatively right now

Dan Morris (agentmorris@gmail.com)
2022-10-19 11:38:10

*Thread Reply:* I did an Important Scientific Experiment:

http://dmorris.net/misc/southern_roller.mp3

😁 Sara Beery, Jinsu Elhance
🕺 Matt Weldy, Jinsu Elhance
👿 Howard L Frederick
Ben Weinstein (benweinstein2010@gmail.com)
2022-10-19 12:42:20

*Thread Reply:* This is where I think the ebird part comes in, we would need to map the generative modeling to some abundance distributions. I didn't consider temporal autocorrelation in bouts. It would be interesting just as a test what parts of the natural landscape a generative model fails to reproduce. Not that I have time for any of this (nor does anyone else), but is it possible to pull in xeno canto in large batches? What's the current state of that API?

Matt Weldy (matthewjweldy@gmail.com)
2022-10-25 13:30:28

*Thread Reply:* Lately I've been using a mix of xenocanto and scaper to simulate audio for training and transfer learning (also using some background soundscapes outside of the target species distribution). Scaper does allow the use of distributions to control the frequency that different call types are included.

Thus far it takes a fair amount of supervising because most xenocanto recordings are not clean.

👍 Sara Beery

Andrew Schulz (akschulz@gatech.edu)
2022-10-25 10:55:00

*Thread Reply:* we tried to utilize published literature like this: https://journals.plos.org/ploscompbiol/article?id=10.1371/journal.pcbi.1006914

journals.plos.org
Ten simple rules towards healthier research labs
The negative effects of extremely competitive academic and research environments on the performance and health of researchers are well known and common worldwide. The prevalence of these effects, particularly among early career researchers, calls for a more humane and people-centered way of working within research labs. Although there is growing concern about the urgent need for a better life–work balance when doing science, there are not many examples about how this could be achieved in practice. In this article, I introduce 10 simple rules to make the working environment of research labs more nurturing, collaborative, and people-centered. These rules are directed towards existing and future principal investigators (PIs) but will be of interest to anyone working in a research lab and/or dealing with how to improve working conditions for scientists.
Original URL: https://journals.plos.org/ploscompbiol/article?id=10.1371/journal.pcbi.1006914
Adam Noach (amn55@cam.ac.uk)
2022-10-25 11:04:04

*Thread Reply:* I really appreciate it thank you 🌿

Ben Weinstein (benweinstein2010@gmail.com)
2022-10-25 12:24:39

*Thread Reply:* here is our code of conduct we review with students when they enter the lab. https://wiki.weecology.org/docs/lab-policy-procedures/code-of-conduct/

Weecology Wiki
Code of Conduct | Weecology Wiki
The Code of Conduct governing conduct of lab members

👍 Adam Noach
Adam Noach (amn55@cam.ac.uk)
2022-10-25 12:29:45

*Thread Reply:* Thanks Ben!

Taiki Sakai - NOAA Affiliate (taiki.sakai@noaa.gov)
2022-10-25 17:47:40

*Thread Reply:* Hi Adam! Similar to other responses, our lab also has a code of conduct / shared values that we go over with incoming members. Happy to share it with you if you PM me. Also passing on a message from Anne Simonis, who wrote our document, on some resources that that served as inspiration:

"In 2018, the National Academies produced a report on sexual harassment in academia, which included a tangible list of recommendations described here: Sexual Harassment in Academic Sciences, Engineering, and Medicine - YouTube Dr. Kate Clancy clearly explained why defining our shared values & code of conduct is needed when she was testifying to Congress:

"The way we've tried to fix this problem isn't working, we have decades of evidence to prove it. Let's move away from a culture of compliance and towards a culture of change.......I hope you will join me in encouraging universities and other science workplaces to take a values-into-action approach to eliminating sexual harassment. That means locational, contextual solutions that create respectful and equitable climates for everyone. That means focusing on the behaviors we want to see, not creating fear around the legally actionable ones. And that means creating confidential avenues for women to speak, and to be heard."

I like how Dr. Clancy's lab Code of Conduct has defined shared values, best practices, links to resources, etc. Here's another short, sweet example from Penny Chrisholm's lab."

YouTube
} The National Academies of Sciences, Engineering, and Medicine (https://www.youtube.com/user/nationalacademies)
Sexual Harassment in Academic Sciences, Engineering, and Medicine
Original URL: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=juJu2mg5y5M

Thijs (thijs@q42.nl)
2022-11-21 10:57:30

*Thread Reply:* Though call 🙂 On one hand I believe humans are equal to any other living being and we don't have a special status (that we currently assign to ourselves).

On the other hand, I believe killing other living beings for your own gain is natural. This happens in all animals and plants, for food, territory, etc.

The main problems these days IMO are, the scale at which we are killing, sometimes even seemingly pointlessly. And the fact that many people think they are better then other species, better than nature, or even not thinking they are part of nature at all. Which is total BS in my eyes :)

➕ Chittesh T, Katelyn Morrison
Rita Pucci (rita.pucci85@gmail.com)
2022-12-29 06:35:45

*Thread Reply:* It is a good starting point for discussion. As Thijs, I don't think we are special and I don't think we can assign ourselves a higher status compared to nature/animals, but in the end for medicine we are special. I don't think that we can compare "killing for surviving" which is normal in nature with "killing for surviving" as humans are applying. We kill lots of beings for everything from the potential mortal virus to lipstick.

I cannot say "save the monkey and doesn't matter if you cannot find the cure for cancer" because I want to have the possibility to survive in case of cancer, but I think that the problem is that we give for granted that we can kill everything just for our wellbeing. In any case, it is a really complicated topic, I don't want to kill animals for my well-being but I want to survive in case of disease.

20 minutes ago, I took the medicine for the headache that probably has been experimented on animals, I am feeling bad for the animals and I am feeling relieved from the headache.

Eddie Zhang (ete@ucsb.edu)

Wilfried Thuiller (wilfried.thuiller@univ-grenoble-alpes.fr)
2023-01-16 05:31:31

Dear all, a call for a 3-4 year chair in our University around AI. Could obviously be developped for conservation.

Call for Research Fellow Chairs 2023

MIAI, the Grenoble Interdisciplinary Institute in Artificial Intelligence (https://miai.univ-grenoble-alpes.fr/), is opening three research fellow chairs in AI reserved to persons who have spent most of their research career outside France (see below). MIAI is one of the four AI institutes created by the French government and is dedicated to AI for the human beings and the environment. Research activities in MIAI aim to cover all aspects of AI and applications of AI with a current focus on embedded and hardware architectures for AI, learning and reasoning, perception and interaction, AI & society, AI for health, AI for environment & energy, and AI for industry 4.0.

These research fellow chairs aim to to address important and ambitious research problems in AI-related fields and will partly pave the way for the future research to be conducted in MIAI. Successful candidates will be appointed by MIAI and will be allocated, for the whole duration of the chair, a budget of 250k€ covering PhD and/or postdoc salaries, internships, travels, … They will be part of MIAI and the French network of AI institutes (comprising, in addition to MIAI, the AI institutes in Paris, Toulouse and Nice) which provide a very dynamic environment for conducting research in AI.

Eligibility To be eligible, candidates must hold a PhD from a non-French university obtained after January 2014 for male applicants and after 2014-n, where n is the number of children, for female applicants. They must also have spent more than two thirds of their research career since the beginning of their PhD outside France. Lastly, they should be pursuing internationally recognized research in AI-related fields (including applications of AI to any research field). To apply Interested candidates should first contact Eric Gaussier (eric.gaussier@univ-grenoble-alpes.fr) to discuss salary and application modalities. It is important to note that candidates should identify a local collaborator working in one of the Grenoble academic research labs with whom they will interact. If selected, they will join the research team of this collaborator. They should then send their application to Manel Boumegoura (manel.boumegoura@univ-grenoble-alpes.fr) and Eric Gaussier (eric.gaussier@univ-grenoble-alpes.fr) by March 11, 2023. Each application should comprise a 2-page CV, a complete list of publications, 2 reference letters, a letter from the local collaborator indicating the relevance and importance of the proposed project, and a 4-page description of the research project which can target any topic of AI or applications of AI. It is important to emphasize, in the description, the ambition, the originality and the potential impact of the research to be conducted, as well as the collaborations the candidate has or will develop with Grenoble researchers in order to achieve her or his research goals. Starting date and duration Each chair is intended for 3 to 4 years, starting no later than September 2023. Location The work will take place in Grenoble, in the research lab of the identified collaborator. For any question, please contact Eric Gaussier (eric.gaussier@univ-grenoble-alpes.fr) or Manel Boumegoura (manel.boumegoura@univ-grenoble-alpes.fr).

David Russell (davidrussell327@gmail.com)
2023-01-16 15:16:58

Hey all, I run a reading group/talk series for robotics (and robotics-adjacent) topics applied to sustainability. We have a slack if you'd like to join yet another one.

We're having our first talk of the year from Marius Wiggert, a PhD student at UC Berkeley and member of the Climate Change AI core team. It's at 1PM EST on 1/24/23 on zoom and you can add it to your gcal https://calendar.google.com/calendar/event?action=TEMPLATE&tmeid=MmtuOHRmajBlbTJ1aWFlcTI5ODQ4aHJjZGIgY181NTgwMzVmODI0MDM4MGI5YjgyY2JjMmRkOGJiMzI4Y2VmZmU4NTE4ZTM1Mzg5MDk1YzY4YTg5ZWY4Njg3NzkzQGc&tmsrc=c_558035f8240380b9b82cbc2dd8bb328ceffe8518e35389095c68a89ef8687793%40group.calendar.google.com|here. The talk description is below.

There are hundreds of solutions to protect our planet, but many of these are too expensive and labor intensive to be applied at the necessary scale. Building on lessons from manufacturing — where robotic automation has had wide success in scaling solutions — many have started to explore the efficacy of robotic automation for climate change solutions. These applications range from scaling reforestation with drones to building solar farms with robots. This webinar will discuss specific applications of a machine learning (ML) in the field of robotics for climate applications in conservation, restoration, and climate change mitigation. In particular, we will discuss the application of ML to coral reef monitoring and restoration and ML to enable autonomy within floating seaweed farms.

accounts.google.com
Google Calendar - Sign in to Access &amp; Edit Your Schedule
Access Google Calendar with a Google account (for personal use) or Google Workspace account (for business use).
Original URL: https://calendar.google.com/calendar/event?action=TEMPLATE&amp;tmeid=MmtuOHRmajBlbTJ1aWFlcTI5ODQ4aHJjZGIgY181NTgwMzVmODI0MDM4MGI5YjgyY2JjMmRkOGJiMzI4Y2VmZmU4NTE4ZTM1Mzg5MDk1YzY4YTg5ZWY4Njg3NzkzQGc&amp;tmsrc=c_558035f8240380b9b82cbc2dd8bb328ceffe8518e35389095c68a89ef8687793%40group.calendar.google.com

Ben Weinstein (benweinstein2010@gmail.com)
2023-01-20 17:07:01

A gentle reminder to machine learning students in the community. I just got absolutely burned by this for like the 3rd time in a week. Different behavior in model.eval(). Unfortunately, the model works about 20% with batchnorm. I want to recommend this set of rants on the dangers of batchnorm, https://www.alexirpan.com/2017/04/26/perils-batch-norm.html https://towardsdatascience.com/curse-of-batch-normalization-8e6dd20bc304, https://twitter.com/jacobmbuckman/status/1391284966340898816.

alexirpan.com
On The Perils of Batch Norm
This post is written for deep learning practitioners, and assumes you know what batch norm is and how it works.
Original URL: https://www.alexirpan.com/2017/04/26/perils-batch-norm.html
Medium
Curse of Batch Normalization
Batch Normalization is Indeed one of the major breakthrough in the field of Deep Learning and is one of the hot topics for discussion…
Reading time
6 min read
Original URL: https://towardsdatascience.com/curse-of-batch-normalization-8e6dd20bc304
twitter
} Jacob Buckman (https://twitter.com/jacobmbuckman/status/1391284966340898816)
The three worst ideas in deep learning are batchnorm, epochs, and overfitting
Original URL: https://twitter.com/jacobmbuckman/status/1391284966340898816
Twitter
👏 Mark Goldwater
👍 Cameron Trotter, Georgia Atkinson, Sara Beery, Caleb Robinson, Ritwik, Lingchao Mao
🙏 Tjomme Dooper
Benjamin Kellenberger (benjamin.kellenberger@yale.edu)
2023-01-20 22:38:16

*Thread Reply:* I've been fighting with catastrophic performance due to batch norm for many years now, going through haphazard workarounds like leaving the batch norm layers in training mode during inference (ugh) or replacing them with instance norm (big compromise). It basically failed on me for whichever dataset I fine-tuned the model on that was not ImageNet (i.e., every single experiment).

👀 Valentin Gabeff
Sara Beery (sbeery@caltech.edu)
2023-02-08 11:59:04

https://www.acm.org/diversity-inclusion/words-matter

acm.org
Words matter: Alternatives for charged terminology in the computing profession
ACM’s efforts to combat exclusion in the computing profession, ACM's Diversity and Inclusion Council has launched "Words Matter," an effort to replace offensive or exclusionary terminology in the computing field. They have developed a list of computing terms to be avoided in professional writing and presentations and offer alternative language. The Council plans to expand this list in the future and invites the community to submit suggestions for consideration.
Original URL: https://www.acm.org/diversity-inclusion/words-matter

Andrzej Białaś (andrzej@appsilon.com)
2023-02-14 15:27:48

Hey everyone, we just published an article (a follow-up of a quick POC we created last year) on using ML to segment copepod prosomes and lipid sacs (or looking at how fat zooplankton are) 🦐🔬🌊

Basically, we're using AI to analyze high-res microscopy images and help researchers better understand how these little critters are affected by climate change and other environmental factors. It's pretty cool stuff.

Our model is making the analysis process faster and more accurate, which means we can gather insights and make progress on marine biology research even faster. 🌍🐟 A paper utilizing the results is on its way (and I’ll be sure to share it when it arrives, but it will take some time)!

Please let me know what you think in the comments! 👍 If you have any questions I’ll be happy to pass them on to our ML team, feel free to comment below or DM me 🥳

Lastly I'll be grateful for recommending whom I could reach out to share our work in this area (if they are not here). Building our Data4Good program we constantly seek partners to help them accelerate research and solve sustainability challenges.

Many thanks! 🤝

appsilon.com
Machine Learning and Plankton: Copepod Prosome and Lipid Sac Segmentation - Data For Good, Machine Learning
Deep learning removes the tedium of plankton structure id. See how we use machine learning for copepod prosome and lipid sac segmentation.
Estimated reading time
8 minutes
Original URL: https://appsilon.com/copepod-prosome-and-lipid-sac-segmentation-with-machine-learning/
😎 Jon Van Oast, Declan, Sara Beery, Stephanie O'Donnell, Lindsey Dukles, Dan Morris, Eileen Li, Lucia Gordon, Jason Holmberg (Wild Me), Emily Charry Tissier
Daniela Schmidt (d.schmidt@bristol.ac.uk)
2023-02-21 09:18:36

*Thread Reply:* I cannot judge the novelty in the CS fields but for someone who works on millions images of plankton, this is the way forward. We are storing video and light images, CT scans and other visuals and do not have the people power to draw all the information out of it. This is a great example of transfer of learning and knowledge.

🙌 Sara Beery
Matt Weldy (matthewjweldy@gmail.com)
2023-02-23 13:08:58

I was wondering if anyone had any reading recommendations (blog, paper, book, etc..) with best practices or clear thinking about building statistical models on top of perception model outputs?

For example, should we be augmenting the stated assumptions of common ecological models (i.e., occupancy) when sensors and perception models are used? What would those stated assumptions look like? How would they change as fine-scale confidence scores are aggregated into detection histories (at a temporal scale that is longer than the sensor processing scale)? Also, how do thresholding decisions affects those assumptions?

And to extend the thinking in Rhinehart et al. (2022) how should I be thinking about perception uncertainty and error propagation when confidence scores are aggregated into detections?

➕ Levi Cai, Sara Beery, Timm Haucke, Emilio Luz-Ricca, Agnethe Seim Olsen
Justin Kitzes (justin.kitzes@pitt.edu)
2023-02-26 10:51:23

*Thread Reply:* Great questions, and ones our group thinks about a lot. I don't really have much to recommend, as I think (at least in ecology) these questions are right on the edge of new research ideas. An important question right away is whether you try to interpret the output of classifiers as a (calibrated) probability or not - the techniques that would come next bifurcate right away (in my opinion) depending on the answer to that question. One way to approach this whole thing is to jump off of the history of occupancy/N-mix/etc modeling, in particular work that allows false positives - I usually recommend the two AHM books (Kery and Royle) for a comprehensive review of what's been done in that space.

👍 Eric Price, Matt Weldy
Matt Weldy (matthewjweldy@gmail.com)
2023-02-27 00:05:14

*Thread Reply:* Thanks! Those are really interesting suggestions. I have spent a little bit of time using false positives rates to adjust aggregated detection frequencies. But I have been using coarse false positive rate estimates (i.e. no spatiotemporal variation in estimates of fpr) so the result is just a rescaled dataset.

I'm excited to see papers from the next few years. It will be interesting to see how some of these questions are resolved (or at least moved forward).

Eric Price (eric.price@ifr.uni-stuttgart.de)
2023-02-27 01:30:20

*Thread Reply:* Confidence scores can be deceiving, especially in classifier networks, due to the softmax function being applied. The confidence is the pseudoprobability of the highest scoring class and gives an approximation of the aleatoric uncertainty with respect to the training data distribution, but does not give a good indication of the epistemic uncertainty (aka does the network know what it is saying or is it guessing) -- there's a blog post explaining that really well: https://towardsdatascience.com/my-deep-learning-model-says-sorry-i-dont-know-the-answer-that-s-absolutely-ok-50ffa562cb0b If a perception model is applied on data far outside of it's training data distribution, one cannot trust the confidence score at all. There will typically be large number of highly confident false positives as well as false negatives. In the blog they use dropout to create a random ensemble of networks and measure the variance across all outputs on the same data to measure epistemic uncertainty. But that's typically hundreds of times slower than running a single network and only suitable for offline methods/processing. In our own work we did some research on treating a perception model as a "sensor" - in this case we need to model the localization error the "sensor" makes. https://doi.org/10.1109/LRA.2018.2850224. i.e. if a true positive has been detected above a certain confidence threshold, how accurate is the localization in pixel space. That can be well approximated by a Gaussian distribution, but needs to be measured across a sufficiently large evaluation set.

Medium
Uncertainty in Deep Learning. How To Measure?
A hands-on tutorial on Bayesian estimation of epistemic and aleatoric uncertainty with Keras. Towards a social acceptance of AI.
Reading time
9 min read
Original URL: https://towardsdatascience.com/my-deep-learning-model-says-sorry-i-dont-know-the-answer-that-s-absolutely-ok-50ffa562cb0b
ieeexplore.ieee.org
Deep Neural Network-Based Cooperative Visual Tracking Through Multiple Micro Aerial Vehicles
Multicamera tracking of humans and animals in outdoor environments is a relevant and challenging problem. Our approach to it involves a team of cooperating microaerial vehicles (MAVs) with on-board cameras only. Deep neural networks (DNNs) often fail at detecting small-scale objects or those that are far away from the camera, which are typical characteristics of a scenario with aerial robots. Thus, the core problem addressed in this letter is how to achieve on-board, online, continuous, and accurate vision-based detections using DNNs for visual person tracking through MAVs. Our solution leverages cooperation among multiple MAVs and active selection of most informative regions of image. We demonstrate the efficiency of our approach through simulations with up to 16 robots and real-robot experiments involving two aerial robots tracking a person, while maintaining an active perception-driven formation. ROS-based source code is provided for the benefit of the community.
Original URL: https://doi.org/10.1109/LRA.2018.2850224
Eric Price (eric.price@ifr.uni-stuttgart.de)
2023-02-27 01:31:42

*Thread Reply:*

Matt Weldy (matthewjweldy@gmail.com)
2023-03-06 14:24:33

*Thread Reply:* I appreciate the replies here. Both have helped me move my thinking a bit on this topic.

We will probably have to do a bit of digging to find relevant work (false positive estimation, uncertainty quantification, model calibration), but I think it will be nice to gather my thoughts on the topic.

Daniel Velasco (daniel.elias.velasco@gmail.com)
2023-03-17 12:05:27

From GPT-4:

“Once upon a time, in the futuristic kingdom of Conservationia, there was a mad (but well-meaning) scientist named Dr. Greenie McSavetheplanet. Dr. Greenie was on a quest to save the world from environmental doom by using the most powerful weapon known to humankind - Artificial Intelligence!

In his secret laboratory, surrounded by lasers and guinea pigs wearing tiny lab coats, Dr. Greenie devised a wacky plan to harness the power of AI to revolutionize conservation science.

Step 1: Dr. Greenie trained a legion of AI-powered robotic squirrels to identify and monitor endangered species in the wild. These fluffy cyber-critters used advanced fur-recognition technology to track the most elusive of animals, even the rare and mysterious Spotted Gigglephant.

Step 2: He created an AI called GreenGenius9000, which could analyze the tweets and burps of every living creature on Earth to detect patterns of habitat destruction. GreenGenius9000 could also predict when and where conservation efforts would be most effective, using a top-secret algorithm that somehow involved tacos and interpretive dance.

Step 3: Dr. Greenie made use of AI-powered drones shaped like oversized bumblebees to replant entire forests at lightning speed. These "Bumble-Boomers" could buzz around the world, planting seeds and high-fiving birds with their tiny drone wings, all in the name of conservation.

With the power of AI and a sprinkle of silliness, Dr. Greenie McSavetheplanet transformed the field of conservation science, making the world a better, greener place for all living beings.

And they all lived happily ever after, except for the occasional AI squirrel going nuts - but that's a tale for another day!”

:squirrel: Agnethe Seim Olsen, Felipe Montealegre-Mora, Malte Pedersen, Andrzej Białaś, John Dziak
👍 Jon Van Oast, Dan Morris, John Dziak
❤️ John Dziak
Felipe Montealegre-Mora (felimomo@berkeley.edu)
2023-03-17 16:32:39

*Thread Reply:* Very cool, and ...

John Dziak (dziakj1@gmail.com)
2023-03-24 09:57:42

I wonder whether this webinar would be useful to anybody here. I think it's free: The International Environmetrics Society (TIES) has launched the TIES Webinar Series on Data Science for Environmental Sciences (DSES). Our next webinar will be on March 31, at 9 am Central Time... You can virtually access the webinar and register via our website: www.environmetrics.xyz Speaker: Claire Monteleoni, Choose France Chair in AI & Research Director (INRIA Paris) and Associate Professor (University of Colorado Boulder) Title: Machine Learning for Climate Change and Environmental Sustainability Abstract: Despite the scientific consensus on climate change, drastic uncertainties remain. Crucial questions about regional climate trends, changes in extreme events, such as heat waves and mega-storms, and understanding how climate varied in the distant past, must be answered in order to improve predictions, assess impacts and vulnerability, and inform mitigation and sustainable adaptation strategies. Machine learning can help answer such questions and shed light on climate change. I will give an overview of our climate informatics research, focusing on challenges in learning from spatiotemporal data, along with semi- and unsupervised deep learning approaches to studying rare and extreme events, and precipitation and temperature downscaling. Bio: Claire Monteleoni is Choose France Chair in AI and Directrice de Recherche at INRIA Paris, an Associate Professor in the Department of Computer Science at the University of Colorado Boulder, and the founding Editor in Chief of Environmental Data Science, a Cambridge University Press journal, launched in December 2020. She joined INRIA in 2023 and has previously held positions at University of Paris-Saclay, CNRS, George Washington University, and Columbia University. She completed her PhD and Masters in Computer Science at MIT and was a postdoc at UC San Diego. She holds a Bachelor's in Earth and Planetary Sciences from Harvard. Her research on machine learning for the study of climate change helped launch the interdisciplinary field of Climate Informatics. She co-founded the International Conference on Climate Informatics, which turns 12 years old in 2023, and has attracted climate scientists and data scientists from over 20 countries and 30 U.S. states. She gave an invited tutorial: Climate Change: Challenges for Machine Learning, at NeurIPS 2014. She currently serves on the NSF Advisory Committee for Environmental Research and Education.

👀 Stephanie O'Donnell, Sara Beery, Lindsey Dukles
Andrzej Białaś (andrzej@appsilon.com)
2023-03-24 12:24:39

📣 Hi everyone, the Appsilon team has been working on improving and adding new features to our Mbaza AI, and life's good.

However, we've recently received reports from some of our users about a "JavaScript error occurred in the main process" message.

We've tried to reproduce this error in-house, but we haven't been able to do so 😮‍💨. Therefore, we're reaching out to you to ask for your help. We'd appreciate it if you could download and install Mbaza AI and see if you encounter the same error.

If you do get the error, please let us know the following information (either DM me here or email at andrzej@appsilon.com please):

  1. Your hardware specifications (CPU, RAM, etc.)
  2. Your operating system (including the version number)
  3. Any other relevant information you think might help us diagnose the problem We're committed to resolving this issue as soon as possible, and your help would be greatly appreciated. Thank you in advance for your time and effort.

🔗 Download link in our GitHub.

Aakash Gupta (aakash@thinkevolveconsulting.com)

👋 Hi everyone, me again, I'm looking to crowdsource some inspiration to make Mbaza better, and I'd like to look through what's available on the market.

❓ Can you please share existing AI solutions that contribute towards biodiversity conservation and monitoring, or otherwise help solve us global sustainability challenges in the 🧵?

Mark Goldwater (mgoldwater@whoi.edu)
2023-03-30 11:46:43

*Thread Reply:* Machine learning has fairly recently (in the last few years) made its way into the field of underwater acoustics. This has made things like source range estimation/localization (among other tasks which are useful for biodiversity monitoring) much easier and great candidates for automation. It would be great to see these techniques integrated into a functional system!

Carly Batist (cbatist@gradcenter.cuny.edu)
2023-03-30 12:00:39

*Thread Reply:* Check out the Conservation Tech Directory 🙂

conservationtech.directory
Conservation Tech Directory
Visit the post for more.
Original URL: https://conservationtech.directory/
🙏 Andrzej Białaś, Sara Beery
Dan Morris (agentmorris@gmail.com)
2023-03-30 18:43:47

*Thread Reply:* For camera traps in particular, here's a list of all the AI-powered systems I know about (including Mbaza!):

https://agentmorris.github.io/camera-trap-ml-survey/

Though it's not totally AI-centric, @Tessa Rhinehart has curated a great list of bioacoustics software, much of which includes some AI functionality, though in the acoustics space, you get into a much fuzzier area around what "AI" is (is spectral template matching "AI"?)

https://github.com/rhine3/bioacoustics-software

All that said, the largest cluster of AI-powered tools being used for conservation is almost definitely in the geospatial space (everything from platform-sized things like Earth Engine to desktop tools like eCognition), and I don't know of a comprehensive survey. Nudge, geospatial ML community?

❤️ Taiki Sakai - NOAA Affiliate, Andrzej Białaś, Sara Beery, Aakash Gupta
🙏 Andrzej Białaś, Valentin Gabeff
Aakash Gupta (aakash@thinkevolveconsulting.com)
2023-03-31 11:48:29

*Thread Reply:* Taking a cue from Carly and Dan, typical use-case in earth observation includes:

  1. Change detection from space - identification of illegal logging incidents
  2. Wildfire detections using IoT sensors - an example will be the platform provided by Dryad.net
  3. Identifying poaching incidents through acoustics - gun-shots through a network of sensors
  4. Solving the last-mile problem of real-time collection of camera trap images. This is an intensive manual task performed by beat officers. Setting up mobile towers in ecologically sensitive areas can be mis-used by poachers. So typically you can look at LoRaWN tech or Mesh networks for hopping signals and edge computing. Though the bandwidth is limited.
  5. Habitat management (grasslands) and watershed management during dry seasons to ensure that prey species have adequate nutrition. Another use cases are getting an accurate count of ungulate population from thermal drone cameras.
Aakash Gupta (aakash@thinkevolveconsulting.com)
2023-03-31 11:58:20

*Thread Reply:* With DeCaTron we have built a data fusion layer on top of the information collected from camera trap images. So you can incorporate GIS information as well as other data from line surveys and daily monitoring along with EO data to understand the spatio-temporal distribution of the population. As well as take proper corrective measures in terms of patrolling of sensitive areas of the reserve forest and habitat management.

Think Evolve Consultancy LLP
Green AI Products – Think Evolve Consultancy LLP
AI Products for a Better tomorrow DeCaTron AI-driven platform for assessing and simulating the biodiversity of forested regions. Contact us to know more DeCaTron is a sophisticated AI-driven platform for assessing and simulating the biodiversity of forested regions. Utilizing advanced machine learning algorithms, the platform can accurately measure the ecological health of a given area … Green AI Products Read More »

1 minute
Original URL: https://www.thinkevolveconsulting.com/green-ai-products/

2023-05-01 17:19:43

I confess i've been somewhat ambivalent about all of the GPT innovations, most just have the veneer of productivity or insight. I thought this one was a bit more interesting. The scispace co-pilot (https://typeset.io/copilot-chrome-plugin). Helpful for scanning papers quickly. Here is an example, that happens to include @Alexandre Lacoste on pretraining remote sensing data. Quick q&a on pdf in browser.

SciSpace - Copilot Chrome plugin
Copilot Chrome Plugin
Copilot Chrome Plugin
Original URL: https://typeset.io/copilot-chrome-plugin
👀 Talia Speaker, Ștefan Istrate, Declan

🎉 Alexandre Lacoste
Alexandre Lacoste (alex.lacoste.shmu@gmail.com)
2023-05-02 09:04:10

*Thread Reply:* I was currently building myself a tool for digesting the literature using GPT4. Let’s how this one is doing.

Alexandre Lacoste (alex.lacoste.shmu@gmail.com)
2023-05-02 09:14:36

*Thread Reply:* The tool that I’m trying to build is slightly different though.

Given a new idea described as text, it searches the web for all papers that might be related. It quickly ranks them by relevance by reading the abstract using GPT 3.5. For the top 10 papers, it reads them in depth with GPT-4 to find the key differences and similarities it also summarizes the papers and important details. Then you can prompt gpt4 with the summary of the top 10 papers and have an in-depth discussion about recommendations for next steps.

Alexandre Lacoste (alex.lacoste.shmu@gmail.com)
2023-05-02 09:15:11

*Thread Reply:* (still work in progress)

Chris Llorca (llorca@terraformation.com)
2023-05-04 14:16:27

It’s exactly one of the issues our science team is dealing with but they don’t have the coding prowess to build their own solution like yourself. Good luck and thanks for your contributions in this space!

Alasdair Davies (alasdair@shuttleworthfoundation.org)
2023-05-10 12:49:40

Hi everyone 👋 This afternoon I have an interesting clip for you all. 👀 A few months ago I posed challenge to two student teams at Oxford University to see if Megadetector V5 could be configured to run inference on live streaming video frames from an RTSP / RTMP source (i.e any live watering hole camera from a publicly accessible YouTube live stream). The objective was to ingress a live stream, process each frame on a local laptop (+ a little GPU support) to output the bounding box as an alpha layer, and then output that inference live to a new stream that could then be re-streamed back out to YouTube from the same laptop - essentially allowing anyone with a YouTube link and a laptop to process the feed to count the number of animals visiting a particular waterhole, assess absence / presence in draught situations etc (+ lots more things).

I wasn't too sure if it would be a laggy experience, but they pulled it off. Here's a little demo or a live restream running at 24fps with real-time detection. @Sara Beery - the answer was yes

🤯 Carly Batist, Taiki Sakai - NOAA Affiliate, Ștefan Istrate, Michael Procko, Toryn Schafer, Sara Beery, Yuru Jia, Timm Haucke, Blair Costelloe, Casey Youngflesh, Yseult Hb, Lindsey Dukles, Mitch Fennell, Emilio Luz-Ricca, Rebekah Loving, Neil Kale
🎉 Pen-Yuan Hsing, Stephanie O'Donnell, Justin Kay, Sara Beery, Chris Llorca, Kalindi Fonda, Yuru Jia, Timm Haucke, Ted Schmitt, Alex Brace, Malte Pedersen, Georgia Atkinson, Yseult Hb
❤️ Joanna Turner, Jon Van Oast, Shivam Shrotriya, Rebekah Loving
🙌 Thomas Radinger, Dan Morris, Agnethe Seim Olsen
Katie Millette (millettek@gmail.com)
2023-05-10 13:25:58

*Thread Reply:* Really cool!! Pardon my ignorance, can you please explain why/what you were expecting to be laggy?

Alasdair Davies (alasdair@shuttleworthfoundation.org)
2023-05-10 13:29:53

*Thread Reply:* It's to do with the speed of the frame capture and processing. It has to process each frame (1920x1080px) at 24 frames per second, generate the bounding box, draw it into a new video frame and then stream it back out to YouTube all in real time, all on the same laptop. I was expecting maybe 15 fps, or even <10, but it's possible to get a smooth experience and just point it at live URLs for instant results

Katie Millette (millettek@gmail.com)
2023-05-10 13:31:53

*Thread Reply:* thanks

Sara Beery (sbeery@caltech.edu)

2023-05-10 16:36:48

Ed Miller (ed@hypraptive.com)
2023-05-11 01:20:42

*Thread Reply:* Very cool! I have done something similar with other object detection models, but not Megadetector (I also didn't re-stream it). This would be a great frontend to the Bearcam Companion (overview) I am working on for the Brooks Falls Bear Cam!

YouTube

Dan Morris (agentmorris@gmail.com)
2023-05-11 10:05:17

*Thread Reply:* Are you running the model at the standard/training resolution (1280px on a side)? That's the default if you use our inference code. If so, I'm quite (pleasantly) surprised by 24 fps! I typically get around 12-13 images per second on an RTX 3090, sometimes (rarely) as high as 20, and if you're getting 24 fps on an RTX 3070, that suggests I'm more limited by disk I/O than I thought I was.

The pessimist in me is concerned about the instability of some of the zebra detections, not sure if that's just a confidence threshold issue, or if that indicates that the model is getting run at a lower-than-typical resolution. What confidence threshold are you using?

Josh Veitch-Michaelis (j.veitchmichaelis@gmail.com)
2023-05-12 12:40:12

*Thread Reply:* This looks great. We did something similar for outreach demos at museums where we'd have a thermal camera rigged up and a live YOLO classifier running on the thermal + RGB streams. It worked fine on a laptop 1060 or so. Generally didn't need to push the resolution too much. This is also how we worked with drone imagery - fly the drone with a WiFi antenna and have a good receiver on the ground. Drone sends back an RTSP stream over e.g. ROS and then we pick it up on the ground and ML happens (or in the air if you prefer, to send back annotated images). Never tried to re-stream it over youtube but I guess you could also easily do it with with something like OBS Studio on Linux (I've used that for streaming games to friends in the past).

Aamir Ahmad (aamir.ahmad@ifr.uni-stuttgart.de)
2023-05-11 16:37:56

Hi everyone. In case you have missed our LinkedIn post, here it goes. TL;DR we have opened up our recent work on learning extremely accurate detectors for animals using purely synthetic data! Have a look here:

https://www.linkedin.com/posts/ahmadaamir_syntheticdata-robotics-drones-activity-7061981286113927168-COKd?utm_source=share&utm_medium=member_desktop

linkedin.com
Aamir Ahmad on LinkedIn: #syntheticdata #robotics #drones #animaldatasets #conservation
Is this the real life? Is this just fantasy? The only way to know it is to check our bleeding-edge work on generating synthetic zebras in wild environments and…
Original URL: https://www.linkedin.com/posts/ahmadaamir_syntheticdata-robotics-drones-activity-7061981286113927168-COKd?utm_source=share&amp;utm_medium=member_desktop
🙌 Stephanie O'Donnell, Jenna Kline, Carly Batist, Viktor Domazetoski, Sara Beery, Andrew Schulz, Yseult Hb, Boyu Zhang, Ben Koger, Jason Holmberg (Wild Me), Talia Speaker, Lucia Gordon, Kristina Kupferschmidt
🎉 Taiki Sakai - NOAA Affiliate, Dan Morris, Jason Holmberg (Wild Me)
:zebra_face: Rowan Converse, Abhay, Jason Holmberg (Wild Me)
George Darrah (george.darrah@systemiq.earth)
2023-06-07 07:07:43

*Thread Reply:* Aamir this is awesome. Re GRADE - would you classify this as 'generative AI' given that you are effectively asking it to render life like zebras as your training data?

Aamir Ahmad (aamir.ahmad@ifr.uni-stuttgart.de)
2023-06-08 13:37:38

*Thread Reply:* Thanks, George! To answer your question -- No, it is not 'generative AI'. The synthetic data generated by GRADE (in our current public version) is not hypothesized (i.e., not sampled from a distribution -- which in turn could have been learned somewhere). What we are doing is purely classic here. We need to start with 'rich' 3D models of animals, with texture, objects or humans. Synthetic images are then generated using ray tracing from any queried view-point in GRADE. Other sensor data (typical for most robots like IMU, odometer, etc) is generated from the known sensor models of various sensors. GRADE is mainly focused on robot perception tasks, therefore I believe using Generative AI-based methods (hypothesizing synthetic data) to generate data for training networks for other downstream tasks in this case could be tricky -- perhaps even dangerous for safety-critical application like collision avoidance. Therefore, we currently have classic approach for it where we use the physics/rendering engine to generate data and add noise on top of it using known sensor models. Perhaps @Elia Bonetto could add if I missed something.

🙏 George Darrah
Atul Ingle (ingle@uwalumni.com)
2023-06-05 18:11:21

Code.org

Ben Weinstein (benweinstein2010@gmail.com)
2023-06-08 13:37:46

Does anyone have experience uploading (large) datasets to google earth engine? I was asked to upload our shapefiles of tree predictions (thousands of shapefiles, tens millions of polygons), and haven't found much luck in using their python api https://stackoverflow.com/questions/48148800/possible-to-upload-shapefiles-in-google-earth-engine-python-api, looks like I should actually create a google bucket and upload as an 'asset' (https://developers.google.com/earth-engine/guides/command_line#upload)?

Stack Overflow
possible to upload shapefiles in google earth engine python api?
Is it possible to upload shapefiles or geoJSON as assets with the Google Earth Engine python API? While it's super easy with the upload tap of the JavaScript API in the Browser, I could not find any
Original URL: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/48148800/possible-to-upload-shapefiles-in-google-earth-engine-python-api
Google for Developers
Command Line Tool  |  Google Earth Engine  |  Google for Developers
Original URL: https://developers.google.com/earth-engine/guides/command_line#upload
Michael Yair (m1cha3l.ya1r@gmail.com)
2023-06-08 15:03:06

*Thread Reply:* Uploading as an asset to cloud storage, is the best practice as the docs recommends, Although, if you chose the Google Earth Engine for querying on map only, as a "free" substitute for GIS, I would suggest to try geopandas. if you already familiar with padnas package and Python programming language, the learning curve will be a walk in the park. The obvious disadvantage is lack of cloud features the Google Earth Engine have.

Leonardo Viotti (leonardoviotti@gmail.com)
2023-06-08 15:58:33

*Thread Reply:* I have uploaded large(ish) files, single digit GBs, as assets through their GUI (code editor), but if you have anything larger this might not be the best solution.

Nico Lang (nila@di.ku.dk)
2023-06-08 16:15:16

*Thread Reply:* I had successful experiences uploading large amount of raster data to GEE via Google Cloud Storage (GCS) buckets. Not sure if the same procedure applies to vector data.

  1. Upload the data to GCS bucket e.g. with rclone.
  2. Create manifest .json file with the uris to the files in the GCS bucket.
  3. Submit an ingestion job with the manifest.json file using earthengine upload
👍 Ben Weinstein
Michael Yair (m1cha3l.ya1r@gmail.com)
2023-06-08 16:41:16

*Thread Reply:* oh... I forgot, on linux system, you can use the fuse to mount the bucket as nfs, and access it as a system folder. https://cloud.google.com/storage/docs/gcsfuse-quickstart-mount-bucket

Google Cloud
Mount a Cloud Storage bucket using Cloud Storage FUSE  |  Google Cloud
Learn how to mount a moonrise-replace22a5e1f19c4846e0b91bd9c5bda96f9emoonrise-replace bucket to a Linux machine using moonrise-replace2007e5b109014d4b9f6acdcb7d2125famoonrise-replace
Original URL: https://cloud.google.com/storage/docs/gcsfuse-quickstart-mount-bucket
Ben Weinstein (benweinstein2010@gmail.com)
2023-06-08 17:54:33

*Thread Reply:* perfect, i'll post any questions, was just confirming this is the right workflow thanks @Nico Lang

👍 Nico Lang
Ben Weinstein (benweinstein2010@gmail.com)

👍 Nico Lang
Michael Yair (m1cha3l.ya1r@gmail.com)
2023-06-09 17:58:54

*Thread Reply:* recently I got a gentle hint from google to start my new applications on cloud run or GKE since they plan to retire the app engine (it is an outsourcing service wrapped in google UI), the migration documentation should be on air already in their blog. https://cloud.google.com/appengine/docs/flexible/run-flex-app-on-kubernetes?tab=python https://cloud.google.com/appengine/docs/standard/cloud-run-for-gae-customers

Google Cloud
Run App Engine apps on GKE  |  Google App Engine flexible environment docs  |  Google Cloud
Original URL: https://cloud.google.com/appengine/docs/flexible/run-flex-app-on-kubernetes?tab=python
Google Cloud
Cloud Run for App Engine customers  |  Google App Engine standard environment docs  |  Google Cloud
Original URL: https://cloud.google.com/appengine/docs/standard/cloud-run-for-gae-customers

Katelyn Morrison (kcmorris@andrew.cmu.edu)
2023-06-11 18:52:28

Hi everyone!

We (@Philipp Spitzer and I) are researchers at Carnegie Mellon University and Karlsruhe Institute of Technology (KIT) seeking to better understand how explanations for artificial intelligence (AI) make predictions more useful, usable, and trustworthy to end-users. To investigate this, we are running a task that asks users to identify images of birds, and then collaborate with AI and generated explanations to arrive at a final identification. Participants will be shown images of birds commonly seen throughout North America and view information from AI such as natural language explanations or example-based explanations to rationalize the bird species classification. The data collected in this research study will be used to identify important characteristics of explanations for image classification under uncertainty when the decision-makers have varying levels of expertise and help us design better explanations for artificial intelligence in general.

This task is part of a research study by Katelyn Morrison at Carnegie Mellon University, IRB STUDY2022_00000062. Participation is voluntary. Participants will be asked to complete a 20-minute-long web-based task. After completing the entire task, participants will be compensated an Amazon gift card of 5 USD at a rate of approximately 15 USD/hour.

If you are interested in participating in this study, please view the study here (https://explanations-9a4b7.web.app/). First, you will be presented with a screening questionnaire to determine if you are eligible to participate in this study. Along with the criteria listed below, you must pass the domain knowledge test (be familiar with birding and/or do bird-related work) and classify 2 of the 3 common ”easy” bird species shown to you correctly. If you are eligible to participate in this study, you will automatically be shown a consent form page to agree to before doing the study task.

Eligibility • 18 years+ • Fluent in English • Living in the U.S. • Previous experience with birding (participated in birding activities and/or doing bird-related work) • Browser Requirements: Chrome/Safari/ Firefox Thanks a lot in advance. If you have any comments, questions, or concerns related to this study, please reach out to me (kcmorris@cs.cmu.edu).

❤️ Sara Beery, Jason Holmberg (Wild Me), Ed Miller, Philipp Spitzer, Timm Haucke, Jon Van Oast, Nicolas Arrieta Larraza, Emily Wanderer, Neil Kale
🦩 Leonardo Viotti, Philipp Spitzer, Toryn Schafer
Ed Miller (ed@hypraptive.com)
2023-06-11 20:25:14

*Thread Reply:* I'll give it a go, and pass it along to a few birders. Always happy to help fellow Tartans!

❤️ Katelyn Morrison, Philipp Spitzer

Hi - this doesn't relate directly to AI for conservation, but wanted to share with the group. I got to work with a fantastic PhD student Nataliya R. to create a guide for creating scientific figures including some base fundamentals through a Figure Rubric & Figure Spectrum for evaluating. If you're interested check it out here: https://github.com/nrokh/ScientificFigures

nrokh/ScientificFigures
A comprehensive guide on how to create beautiful scientific figures for technical publications, presentations, and posters

Florian Shkurti (florian@cs.toronto.edu)
2023-11-19 22:53:51

Hi all,

I'm an assistant professor in computer science at UofT, specializing in robotics and machine learning.

I recently bought an autonomous boat that has a programmable winch, allowing us to move sensors vertically along the water column: https://www.maritimerobotics.com/otter

I'd like to focus on what sensors it would make sense to deploy on this boat, so I am asking people who are interested in aquatic and marine environments for advice on what's worth measuring to advance their research.

Would something like https://www.ysi.com/exo3?gad=1&gclid=CjwKCAjwp8OpBhAFEiwAG7NaEo9oY7kUdxORTGJYPdPOPP-UEp5pl6y6B2KmrnYZfOODRrPMz7ruuhoCZg0QAvD_BwE|this multiparameter sonde work for you or for people in your area? If not, do you have any other sensors that you would like to deploy? I've also looked at RBR sensors for real-time measurements.

I'm currently looking into underwater hyperspectral cameras, as well as flow cytometers for plankton or microplastics.

Ideally, these sensors would allow for in-situ analysis, but I'm open to any suggestions that might make this robotic platform useful for scientists in your research area.

Thanks, Florian

Cody Kupferschmidt (kupfersc@uoguelph.ca)
2023-11-23 14:54:31

*Thread Reply:* Hi @Florian Shkurti, have you considered an ADCP? https://www.whoi.edu/what-we-do/explore/instruments/instruments-sensors-samplers/acoustic-doppler-current-profiler-adcp/

I know that some researchers are using these to measure frazil ice concentration, so I suspect they may also work for plankton and plastics.

Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution
Acoustic Doppler Current Profiler (ADCP) - Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution
The ADCP is an instrument that measures how fast water currents move across the water column with sound, using a principle of sound waves called the Doppler effect.
Original URL: https://www.whoi.edu/what-we-do/explore/instruments/instruments-sensors-samplers/acoustic-doppler-current-profiler-adcp/
Florian Shkurti (florian@cs.toronto.edu)
2023-12-01 15:11:06

*Thread Reply:* Thanks so much @Cody Kupferschmidt, I'll take a more detailed look. Do you know the names of the researchers who are using this for ice concentration?

Cody Kupferschmidt (kupfersc@uoguelph.ca)
2023-12-01 18:57:12

Ben Williams (ben.williams.20@ucl.ac.uk)
2023-12-07 09:36:31

*Thread Reply:* Do you have habitats and/or field sites in mind?

Here are some rambling thoughts: • I work mainly on studying the health of coral reefs using acoustics and ML. We collect audio with Soundtraps and now mostly Hydromoths, plenty of other hydrophones out there too. • One of my projects uses a CNN trained on hydromoth recordings to detect bomb fishing. We are working in collaboration with SFB who have started putting hydrophones on blue boats (similar to the Otter it would seem). This is to try and allow roaming detection of bombing events https://www.sfbusa.org/ • We also work at the worlds largest reef restoration program which is a pretty great place to do science. We often collect images for photogrammetry and benthic surveys using divers, but as this is so shallow (~2m) I've been aware things like the Otter could do this but better. A field season is now being planned for 2024. • For this same purpose, hyperspectral images would be fantastic. These have been shown to improve bleaching detection/coral ID, and I would love to play with chucking those extra channels into a CNN and seeing how it improves benthic classification. If any of that is of interest, do please contact me on ben.williams.20@ucl.ac.uk

sfbusa.org
Stop Fish Bombing USA
Stop Fish Bombing USA has developed underwater bomb location technology to help detect and alert law enforcement and to ultimately eradicate this practice.
Original URL: https://www.sfbusa.org/
Mars Coral
The growing scientific effort at HOPE Reef- Mars Coral
Building Coral
Original URL: https://www.buildingcoral.com/news/the-growing-scientific-effort-at-hope-reef
🌊 Steve Haddock, Shir Bar, Omiros Pantazis, Clare Price
🙌:skin_tone_3: Alan Stenhouse

🌡️  ERA5 data from @CopernicusECMWF indicates that 17 November was the first day that the global temperature exceeded 2°C above pre-industrial levels, reaching 2.07°C above the 1850-1900 average and the provisional ERA5 value for 18 November is 2.06°C.

Brittany Salas (brittany@sadu.io)
2024-02-08 17:21:55

Hi everyone! NxyCarbon is hosting a sustainable finance event at the end of the month. We’re diving deep into demand signals for ecosystem restoration, biodiversity, and carbon removal, while going over all the ways to finance a project in these areas.

🎈Register here to join the conversation https://lu.ma/nyxcarbon1 🎈

The carbon market has been around for a couple of decades, and has thus far played a key role in sustainable finance, but will it continue amid policy change and calls for greater transparency? Are there other, better, ways to finance carbon removal and ecosystem restoration? Listen to industry veterans chat about the macro and micro forces driving demand for environmental services.

The conversation will be led by: Brittany Salas, CEO & Founder, NyxCarbon Nate Wyne CEO & Co-founder, Floodlight Randy Wilgis COO, Earth Recovery Partners

🔐 NyxCarbon is a lending platform that makes it easy for financial institutions to provide loans to SMEs in carbon removal and ecosystem restoration. The end-to-end solution reduces the cost of underwriting providing targeted market intelligence and automating loan servicing.

🔍 Floodlight is a geospatial data intelligence company providing an extensive catalog of Environmental, Social, and Governance Datasets by leveraging ground sensors, aerial satellites, and artificial intelligence.

🌲 Earth Recovery Partners mobilizes enterprises and projects to solve the world’s environmental problems through nature-based solutions, environmental markets, and technology.

lu.ma
Carbon Carrots and Sticks: Who pays for carbon removal or ecosystem restoration and why? · Luma
Join the debate. The carbon market has been around for a couple of decades, and has thus far played a key role in sustainable finance, but will it continue amid policy change and calls for...
Original URL: https://lu.ma/nyxcarbon1
Mohit Dubey (mohit.dubey96@gmail.com)
2024-02-08 22:11:08

Thank You!!

Shir Bar (shirbar@tauex.tau.ac.il)
2024-02-18 08:10:05

Hi all! We're looking for recommendations for a data management tool for the lab. We're trying to index our labs's video collection and create a database of all the files we have and their various properties. The goal is to later be able to query this database so we can easily find videos that fall into certain categories (e.g., 2-d videos of damselfish taken in the field with annotations). Preferably this should be some sort of GUI so that even none coding students could use it. If anyone has any leads I would love to hear them, thanks!

Michael Yair (m1cha3l.ya1r@gmail.com)
2024-02-18 08:51:55

*Thread Reply:* As far as I know (at least 2 cases), labs creates such tools for themselves (outsourcing or bringing student with relevant background).

It requires some kind of schema of metadata bounded to the video file itself. To make in available for queries - it requires some kind of standard DB (SQL, Document etc.). Since those are video file - extreme storage consumers, you need a lot of space to store them.

There are some considerations to take here - • Would you like the data to be on site or on cloud service? • Should it be available world wide or only for lab internal use? • Is this data collection going to persists along the time, or is it time limited for specific research? I would start with evaluating the required space annually - it seems to be the most expensive part in the project.

🙏 Shir Bar
👍 Justin Kay
Eric Price (eric.price@ifr.uni-stuttgart.de)
2024-02-18 09:53:33

*Thread Reply:* I'd also say SQL based - you could use MariaDB or MySQL - and use PHPMyAdmin as a web based GUI for the students. The actual videos don't need to be stored in the DB, I think it makes more sense to just store file paths/urls where the actual raw video can be found and use the DB only for metadata.

👍 Shir Bar, Justin Kay
Shir Bar (shirbar@tauex.tau.ac.il)
2024-02-18 10:04:05

*Thread Reply:* Great! Thank you both. We were thinking along the lines of what you were suggesting Eric - just storing the paths with the metadata, especially since we have the videos spread across several storage solutions. We're just rather clueless about SQL and what solutions are out there to interact with the DB once it's built, and our googling just led us to a variety of paid solutions.

Eric Price (eric.price@ifr.uni-stuttgart.de)
2024-02-18 10:14:36

*Thread Reply:* SQL typically uses an SQL server that acts as a storage backend and ensures database integrity, and a client, which connects to the server via socket or tcp/ip and issues queries in the SQL language. queries are used for everything from • setting up databases or changing them (maintenance) • entering data in the database • querying for data (search/retrieval) clients range from a simple maintenance commandline client in which SQL is entered by hand or read from a script file, to complex applications that use an SQL backend for their data, to websites which have a SQL based webend. unless you have great knowledge of SQL databases the commandline client is too cumbersome and you probably don't want to write your own application or web-app just for the video-data. so the go to app is an existing general purpose SQL maintenance and data entry/query user interface. for MySQL the default that everyone uses is PHPMyAdmin. It's a web-app written in PHP that you can run on the same server as the database itself and allows everything from drag-and-paint database relation design to easy search of data to bulk data entry, maintenance tasks, everything. it also has great docu. basically everyone who works with open source databases uses it - and its fully open source and free.

on a debian, you can install it all just with "apt install mysql-server phpmyadmin" and you have a local database server and a web frontend to work with it - i think it installs on http://localhost/phpmyadmin per default

🙌 Shir Bar
Eric Price (eric.price@ifr.uni-stuttgart.de)
2024-02-18 10:15:26

*Thread Reply:* also works on any debian derivates like ubuntu

Aakash Gupta (aakash@thinkevolveconsulting.com)
2024-02-18 11:08:19

*Thread Reply:* If the metadata and annotations are in an excel file, it will be easy for you to import it into a SQL tool, and then use some kind of NLP-query engine to search for specific information.

🎯 Eric Price, Sara Beery
👍 Shir Bar
Shir Bar (shirbar@tauex.tau.ac.il)
2024-02-19 00:23:06

*Thread Reply:* Whoah, great intro to SQL! Thanks so much I really appreciate it! And, really cool idea Aakash, thanks!

Eric Orenstein (eorenstein@mbari.org)
2024-02-25 13:04:13

*Thread Reply:* Shir, if you're doing ocean specific stuff you might find MBARI's Video Annotation and Reference System helpful. It has been developed over the past 20 some odd years and is what the institution uses to organizes its (extensive) collection of ROV videos. Supports domain specific metadata, etc.

mbari-org/m3-quickstart
A simple and quick method to run MBARI's Video Annotation and References System
Stars
1
Language
Python
👍 Shir Bar

Levi Cai (lcai@whoi.edu)
2024-02-26 15:07:19

Dear all users of robots/drones for ecology/conservation!

We are excited to announce a new workshop titled "Robots for Understanding Natural Ecosystems" that we're hosting at the upcoming ICRA 2024, in Yokohama, Japan on May 17th!

The workshop invites roboticists who work in ecology or ecologists who work with robots to come and share their findings and discuss the future of these technologies and their role in ecology and conservation topics!

To find out more visit the website: https://warp.whoi.edu/rune or feel free to reach out to me on this slack!

Best, -ICRA 2024 RUNE Organizers

sites.google.com
RUNE Workshop @ ICRA 2024
ABSTRACT Natural ecosystems are defined by complex webs of interactions between the flora, fauna, and non-organic elements of an environment. The importance of modeling and understanding these entangled and dynamic interactions is increasing as anthroprogenic change threatens ecosystems across the
Original URL: https://warp.whoi.edu/rune
Brandon Hays (brandon.hays@duke.edu)
2024-02-27 12:24:17

*Thread Reply:* I definitely won't be able to attend, but I'd love to read a synthesis paper if you all write up the themes of the workshop!

🙏 Levi Cai
Xiaojuan Liu (xjliu@climatechange.ai)
2024-02-28 14:49:14

Dear AI for Conservation community! My name is Xiaojuan, and I’m a research scientist at Climate Change AI (CCAI). I’m reaching out to see if any of you would be open to participating in either a 60-minute group virtual workshop session or a one-on-one interview focused on critical data gaps in using machine learning for work in biodiversity/ecosystems. CCAI, partnering with Google DeepMind, is conducting a global stocktake of critical data gaps that inhibit effective machine learning (ML) solutions to climate-related challenges. The goal of this initiative is to report on the most important data gaps, and lay out pathways for funders, data providers, and researchers to address them.

If you’re interested in joining the group workshop, may I ask you to indicate your availability in the following poll (by March 15): http://whenisgood.net/3xpsa9c?

If you’re interested in participating in a one-on-one interview, please book a time here: https://calendar.app.google/RbDx9GkeDiVxBYJA8

Thank you, and we hope you can join us!

whenisgood.net
WhenIsGood: CCAI Data Gaps Virtual Workshop
Plan the time to have your meeting or event by coordinating availability with all the participants using this fuss-free online tool.
Original URL: http://whenisgood.net/3xpsa9c
👍 Justin Kay, Carly Batist, Sara Beery, Liping Li
🙌 Jennifer
Nate Harada (nharada1@gmail.com)

2024-03-13 20:01:34
