Nate Harada (nharada1@gmail.com)
2024-03-13 20:38:43

I think the techniques seem similar, but I was more curious if the actual process is similar, since I’m under the impression that for something like this an environmental consulting firm is contracted to do the actual work. This Slack seems much more academia and non-profit focused although that might be just a bias of the limited contact I’ve had with folks so far.

Evan Eskew (eveskew@gmail.com)
2024-03-14 14:06:59

Hi Nate, the lab of Brian Todd, my PhD advisor did a lot of related work on desert tortoises in the Mojave. My impression is that for both sensitive species discovery and management, developers often rely on environmental consultants. There is massive time and financial costs to these endeavors. In the case of the desert tortoise, which is listed by the Endangered Species Act as a threatened species, my understanding is developers were given strict quotas regarding the number of animals that could be harmed incidentally during the development process. As a result, one of the articles I’m linking mentions that BrightSource spent >$50 million to try to mitigate harms to the desert tortoise during their solar development of the Ivanpah Valley! This included millions of dollars of fencing to keep tortoises from getting hit on roads. But then the tortoises encounter the fences, sometimes pace them in frustration, and die of thermal exposure as a result. To counteract that, my understanding was that they hired biologists/consultants to literally walk the fences every day, intervening with any pacing tortoises they would encounter. A real mess!

TLDR: solar development has complex environmental impacts and right now mitigation of those impacts is extremely costly in terms of time and money

😮 Jon Van Oast, Nate Harada, Ghazi Randhawa
💚 Jon Van Oast, Nate Harada, Ghazi Randhawa
👀 Steve Haddock, Maricela Abarca
🐢 Burak Ekim
Evan Eskew (eveskew@gmail.com)
2024-03-14 14:07:40

UC Davis
Desert Tortoises Can’t Take the Heat of Roadside Fencing
Desert tortoises pace back and forth and can overheat by roadside fencing meant to help them, according to a study published in the journal Biological Conservation by the University of California, Davis, and the University of Georgia.
Original URL: https://www.ucdavis.edu/news/desert-tortoises-can%E2%80%99t-take-heat-roadside-fencing

Patrick Beukema (patrickb@allenai.org)
2024-04-25 13:52:46

I gave an interview on the MLOps podcast and spoke about the unique challenges in Environmental AI and some of the lessons we have learned building AI for conservation and sustainability. This is not intended to be shameless self promotion (although I know it may come across that way), but I do hope that it may be useful to some of the teams here, and of course I am very grateful for any feedback on the ideas/how we might grow/do a better job (technical or otherwise). https://podcasts.apple.com/us/podcast/beyond-agi-can-ai-help-save-the-planet-patrick-beukema-225/id1505372978?i=1000653011203 Beyond AGI, Can AI Help Save the Planet? // Patrick Beukema // #225

🎉 Dan Morris
Ben Weinstein (benweinstein2010@gmail.com)
2024-05-06 14:28:23

If anyone else had legacy data in which annotators had counted items in photoshop, I managed to figure out how to export the locations of the markers https://github.com/weecology/EvergladesTools/blob/main/photoshop/counts.jsx and I made a video (that was meant for internal use, sorry i'm talking fast to the head of my field team). You do then need to fill in the labels in a csv file. Not bad for recovering very old data. https://www.loom.com/share/5ac181c1a8884194825766589c9642d5

Loom
Loom Message - 23 August 2022
Original URL: https://www.loom.com/share/5ac181c1a8884194825766589c9642d5
<https://github.com/weecology/EvergladesTools/blob/main/photoshop/counts.jsx | counts.jsx>
<pre><code>var ci = app.activeDocument.countItems var plist = "ItemNumber\tXpos\tYpos\timage\n" var tp = Folder.desktop + "/CountItem.txt"; for (var i = 0; i &lt; ci.length; i++){ var pos = ci[i].position.toString().split(",") var group = ci[i].parent.toString() plist += (i+1) + "\t" + pos[0] +"\t" + pos[1] + "\t" + group + "\n" }; writeText(tp, plist) /**** ** Write a text file ** the file path ** the text ** **/ function writeText(p,s){ var file = new File(p.toString()); file.encoding = 'UTF-8'; file.open('w'); file.write(s); file.close(); } </code></pre>
<a href="https://github.com/weecology/EvergladesTools">weecology/EvergladesTools</a>

Ben Weinstein (benweinstein2010@gmail.com)
2024-06-05 14:09:00

Does anyone have experience with ecological data and object detection methods that explicitly use pixels and context from outside the prediction detection/anchor box to inform detection classification? Is this one of the places that the YOLO type models differ? I feel like I should know the answer to this. Clearly important for animals that occur in groups. I'm reading about box attention here https://arxiv.org/pdf/2111.13087. Maybe @Nate Harada or @Oisin Mac Aodha. There are lots of post-processing methods like conditional random fields(@Benjamin Kellenberger’s paper here: https://zslpublications.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/full/10.1002/rse2.200), but I'd like to learn the spatial attention. Does anyone think this is worth the effort?

Sara Beery (sbeery@caltech.edu)
2024-06-05 14:47:01

*Thread Reply:* I believe the features in YOLO-style models should have context from outside the box, even after region cropping in feature space. But that context will be stronger from near than far. This was one of the things we were trying to capture in a more object-centric way with the cross-box attention on context r-cnn, but that's pretty old school at this point

☝️ Oisin Mac Aodha, Justin Kay, Joseph Dimos
Oisin Mac Aodha (macaodha@caltech.edu)
2024-06-05 15:17:46

*Thread Reply:* We have some experiments in this paper (Table 2) where we should the benefit of context from outside the region of interest when detecting bat calls in audio: https://www.biorxiv.org/content/10.1101/2022.12.14.520490v1.full.pdf+html

Connor Levenson (clevenson@ucsb.edu)
2024-06-05 18:06:44

*Thread Reply:* You can also check out some experiments we did here on this. For YOLO I think this should be learned implicitly, but idt I have seen anyone do a SHAP-esque analysis to get an understanding of how those features are helping/hurting.

arXiv.org
Context-Driven Detection of Invertebrate Species in Deep-Sea Video
Each year, underwater remotely operated vehicles (ROVs) collect thousands of hours of video of unexplored ocean habitats revealing a plethora of information regarding biodiversity on Earth. However, fully utilizing this information remains a challenge as proper annotations and analysis require trained scientists time, which is both limited and costly. To this end, we present a Dataset for Underwater Substrate and Invertebrate Analysis (DUSIA), a benchmark suite and growing large-scale dataset to train, validate, and test methods for temporally localizing four underwater substrates as well as temporally and spatially localizing 59 underwater invertebrate species. DUSIA currently includes over ten hours of footage across 25 videos captured in 1080p at 30 fps by an ROV following pre planned transects across the ocean floor near the Channel Islands of California. Each video includes annotations indicating the start and end times of substrates across the video in addition to counts of species of interest. Some frames are annotated with precise bounding box locations for invertebrate species of interest, as seen in Figure 1. To our knowledge, DUSIA is the first dataset of its kind for deep sea exploration, with video from a moving camera, that includes substrate annotations and invertebrate species that are present at significant depths where sunlight does not penetrate. Additionally, we present the novel context-driven object detector (CDD) where we use explicit substrate classification to influence an object detection network to simultaneously predict a substrate and species class influenced by that substrate. We also present a method for improving training on partially annotated bounding box frames. Finally, we offer a baseline method for automating the counting of invertebrate species of interest.
Original URL: https://arxiv.org/abs/2206.00718
Dan Morris (agentmorris@gmail.com)
2024-06-05 18:08:18

*Thread Reply:* I don't know how to quantify "explicitly", but YOLOv5 definitely weights nearby pixels a lot, even compared to pixels inside the box. E.g. sometimes it seems really impressive that MegaDetector finds people in the windows of cars, but it's a parlor trick; MD also hallucinates a lot of people in car windows, it's just learned what car windows look like, and that somewhere inside the window (but not taking up the whole window), there is often a person.

Ben Weinstein (benweinstein2010@gmail.com)
2024-06-05 20:10:39

*Thread Reply:* Do you think there is something particular about the yolo style models that are more likely to learn these kind of context features compared to torchvision style retinanet/maskRCNN or the vision transformers?

Eric Price (eric.price@ifr.uni-stuttgart.de)
2024-06-13 03:56:29

*Thread Reply:* SSD Multibox and related networks uses convolution layers above the classification - so there is context information based on the convolution kernel size outside of the bounding box but with a limited range - this gets more interesting when using "feature fusion SSD"s since the network gathers data from the whole image in the top layer and than feeds it back to the detection layer through deconvolutions - via that route the network can take information from the whole image into account for localization and classification of any indivudual object regardless of size -

👍 Ben Weinstein
👍:skin_tone_3: Alan Stenhouse
Eric Price (eric.price@ifr.uni-stuttgart.de)
2024-06-13 03:58:35

*Thread Reply:* just checked according to the architecture here: https://iq.opengenus.org/yolov5/ yolo5 does exactly that - it pools information from the whole image through the neck - so in principle - if the training data supports that - far spacial relationships can be taken into account

OpenGenus IQ: Learn Algorithms, DL, System Design
YOLO v5 model architecture [Explained]
Since 2015 the Ultralytics team has been working on improving this model and many versions since then have been released. In this article we will take a look at the fifth version of this algorithm YOLOv5.
Written by
CHERIFI Imane
Filed under
Machine Learning (ML), Deep Learning
Original URL: https://iq.opengenus.org/yolov5/
Josh Veitch-Michaelis (j.veitchmichaelis@gmail.com)
2024-07-06 20:43:56

*Thread Reply:* Somewhat related https://arxiv.org/abs/1612.04402 - a good discussion on improving tiny object detection with varying sized context windows. Not sure how relevant it is nowadays with a lot of models using FPN to combine features from different layers

arXiv.org
Finding Tiny Faces
Though tremendous strides have been made in object recognition, one of the remaining open challenges is detecting small objects. We explore three aspects of the problem in the context of finding small faces: the role of scale invariance, image resolution, and contextual reasoning. While most recognition approaches aim to be scale-invariant, the cues for recognizing a 3px tall face are fundamentally different than those for recognizing a 300px tall face. We take a different approach and train separate detectors for different scales. To maintain efficiency, detectors are trained in a multi-task fashion: they make use of features extracted from multiple layers of single (deep) feature hierarchy. While training detectors for large objects is straightforward, the crucial challenge remains training detectors for small objects. We show that context is crucial, and define templates that make use of massively-large receptive fields (where 99% of the template extends beyond the object of interest). Finally, we explore the role of scale in pre-trained deep networks, providing ways to extrapolate networks tuned for limited scales to rather extreme ranges. We demonstrate state-of-the-art results on massively-benchmarked face datasets (FDDB and WIDER FACE). In particular, when compared to prior art on WIDER FACE, our results reduce error by a factor of 2 (our models produce an AP of 82% while prior art ranges from 29-64%).
Original URL: https://arxiv.org/abs/1612.04402

Travel support is available, for flights/accommodation (or other transpo). Come visit beautiful Ashland!

Ben Weinstein (benweinstein2010@gmail.com)
2024-07-09 14:02:14

I've been reading https://www.researchsquare.com/article/rs-3832815/v1 Has anyone spent time on a 'species not in the class' alert system for human review, many of the zero shot tools from outside ecology and anomaly detection ideas end up finding 1) smeared or non-recognizable detections, 2) non-biological objects that were incorrectly detected. I'm thinking about ways that we can find new bird species in UAV imagery after first using a 'bird' detector and classifying each crop. When the model believes that it has found something of interest, and it reaches a reasonable objectness and salience threshold, send to humans to look at. Maybe @Eric Orenstein and fathomnet team. General CV review here: https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s11263-024-02117-4

Research Square
Accelerating the discovery of biodiversity by detecting “new” species based on machine learning method
Background Recently, machine learning (ML) has been widely used in species auto-identification systems for multi-scene applications in biodiversity, while most of the existing ML systems relying on images are limited to identifying the species on which they are trained, and unknown sp...
Original URL: https://www.researchsquare.com/article/rs-3832815/v1
SpringerLink
Generalized Out-of-Distribution Detection: A Survey
International Journal of Computer Vision - Out-of-distribution (OOD) detection is critical to ensuring the reliability and safety of machine learning systems. For instance, in autonomous driving,...
Original URL: https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s11263-024-02117-4
🤯 Jon Van Oast, Bernie Boscoe, Don Cosseboom, Robin Zbinden, Burak Ekim
👍 Chris Lange
👀 Alan Stenhouse
Levi Cai (lcai@whoi.edu)
2024-07-09 14:23:46

*Thread Reply:* We have also been (super loosely) thinking about this type of thing, and I think generally agree with the multi-stage style approach. Basically the most-specific object detector/classifier you can arrive at "above" the target classifier (MegaDetector's a good start, bird detector if you have that, etc.) and then whatever level it is unable to produce a reasonable confidence threshold, raise that as something needing humans to review. If you have lots of data in this manner, you can attempt some flavor of unsupervised clustering to see if you can find some groups that might be a missing species or some other systemic issue.

👍 Ben Weinstein
👍:skin_tone_3: Alan Stenhouse
Cameron Trotter (cater@bas.ac.uk)
2024-07-10 04:40:56

*Thread Reply:* I did something similar for individual re-ID on dolphins during my PhD, so same species but the methods could apply I believe.

The problem of classification was open-set, as there was no guarantee all individuals had been previously ID'd and were in the catalogue. We trained a Siamese Neural Network on examples of all known individuals. Once trained, examples of the same individual would generate similar embeddings which could then be clustered. Previously unseen individuals would in theory generate dissimilar embeddings, and based on some distance threshold could be flagged for manual review. Generating new clusters could be done by storing the new embeddings in some database for future comparison, though due to covid we couldn't do further fieldwork to expand the catalogue and test how effective that was.

The problem is central to my current project, detecting taxa in Antarctic Southern Ocean sea floor imagery. Here there is a much higher chance of the data containing new species (both to our dataset and science), so having a robust way to flag potential new species is key. Very keen to discuss work in this area.

🌍 Alan Stenhouse
Chris Lange (s2125675@ed.ac.uk)
2024-07-10 09:47:47

*Thread Reply:* Interesting stuff. I have recently attempted to do something related (haven't had much success but still working on it!) where we attempt to discover ``new" species currently miscategorised into existing classes using online, community collected observations of those species (iNaturalist basically).

I also went with a "learn useful features for classification into existing classes -> look for clusters in this feature space -> use some metric of distance or dissimilarity between clusters to identify potentially new species" approach, possibly similar to yours @Cameron Trotter

Anyway I need to look into it but maybe these beetle datasets will be helpful. I still have a lot of stuff in this area to explore for now.

Cameron Trotter (cater@bas.ac.uk)
2024-07-10 09:48:51

*Thread Reply:* Yes @Chris Lange sounds very similar!

👍 Chris Lange
Ben Weinstein (benweinstein2010@gmail.com)
2024-07-10 09:58:17

*Thread Reply:* My first pass at these approaches is that they are excellent in finding very different objects than target classes, so they are good enough for data cleaning. For example from the UAV birds, when we've detected a distant boat instead of a bird, but they are too coarse to find the fine-grained differences that differentiate species. We need some kind of salience based fine-grained detector,

👍 Chris Lange, Sara Beery
👍:skin_tone_3: Alan Stenhouse
Chris Lange (s2125675@ed.ac.uk)
2024-07-10 10:10:54

*Thread Reply:* Yeah, I would say that so far the most common "new species" I identify are just cases where photos show evidence of the presence of a species in a form that isn't actually an image of the animal (such as nests, scat, etc).

Sara Beery (sbeery@caltech.edu)
2024-07-10 12:10:03

*Thread Reply:* @Nico Lang has a really nice paper formalizing what Ben just said: https://openaccess.thecvf.com/content/CVPR2024/html/Lang_From_Coarse_to_Fine-Grained_Open-Set_Recognition_CVPR_2024_paper.html

👍 Chris Lange, Ben Weinstein, Cameron Trotter
👍:skin_tone_3: Alan Stenhouse
Ben Weinstein (benweinstein2010@gmail.com)
2024-07-10 13:37:24

*Thread Reply:* Just read, @Nico Lang that's a great and well written paper. For those in the thread that haven't looked at the paper, one interesting takeaway is that hierarchical models, which have been shown to improve within set accuracy and 'make better mistakes', actively hinder novel class detection by increasing the similarity of species, for example within a genus. By discouraging hierarchical structure, you get a small, but meaningful bump in novel class detection. This result, coupled with another result showing the complexities of label granularity for the supervised classes underlines how hard its going to be develop a single model that can be used to both classify species AND recognize novel ones. This feels like a problem that will need to be addressed in two separate stages. @Nico Lang jump in if I misinterpreted anything. If you have any thoughts on where to continue to take this, feel free to throw out ideas.

🙌 Chris Lange
Elizabeth Bondi-Kelly (ecbk@umich.edu)
2024-07-10 19:37:26

*Thread Reply:* My lab and I are super interested in human-AI collaboration in general, and I’m not sure we’ve looked at this exactly, but we have two papers where we’ve started thinking about related ideas (the more recent one with @Sara Beery and @Vaibhav Balloli), if maybe helpful: https://arxiv.org/abs/2112.06751, https://realize-lab.github.io/CHAIR/static/pdfs/IJCAICHAIRCameraReady.pdf

🙌:skin_tone_3: Alan Stenhouse
Ben Weinstein (benweinstein2010@gmail.com)
2024-07-10 21:34:36

*Thread Reply:* Really great @Elizabeth Bondi-Kelly, I like the general narrative alot. On a similar theme, there is alot of statistical work to be done to think about how to sample large image datasets for human-AI collaboration. Imagine you are working with a management agency that wants 90% accuracy for species classification and animal counts in 1.5 million images (as we are), and you don't want human review of all images. How to develop bayesian type models to estimate the likelihood that pipeline, rather than the model, has a certain accuracy and therefore the mission is complete. Given the nonuniform distribution of classes, how/when can we say that the set of images reaches as certain performance threshold given limited capacity for human-review. It seems pretty safe to say that random sampling won't do it, it will need to be some kind of embeddings informed sampling. Related to the model ideas above.

💯 Vaibhav Balloli, Sara Beery, Elizabeth Bondi-Kelly, Alan Stenhouse
Elizabeth Bondi-Kelly (ecbk@umich.edu)
2024-07-11 11:34:45

*Thread Reply:* Definitely - thank you! Let me know if you'd like to chat more, we'd love to follow up 🙂

Ștefan Istrate (stefan.istrate@gmail.com)

iWildCam 2022 - LILA BC
Overview This dataset contains approximately 260,000 camera trap images with species-level annotations derived from the WCS Camera Traps dataset, with additional metadata and supplementary training data not included in the original WCS Camera Traps dataset. This dataset was used for the iWildCam 2022 competition as part of the FGVC9 workshop at CVPR 2022. Original results...

Dan Morris (agentmorris@gmail.com)
2024-07-25 19:01:35

Let's play a game... how many camera trap images do we think have ever been collected? Let's leave video out of it for now to avoid questions about whether a frame counts as an image. Bonus points for guessing how many camera trap images were collected in the last year (presumably camera trap image volume is increasing with time).

I wish there were a way to decide who wins this game, but I have no idea what the answer is. So I'm not sure whether it's even really a game. I guess no one wins at Minecraft either, and Minecraft is a game.

There is no secret motivation behind this game, I was just inspired by the #random channel.

I have a guess for both questions, but I'll hold my guesses until others have guessed, it would be lame if I posted the question and made the first guess.

💯 Carly Batist
😀 Alan Stenhouse, Talia Speaker
Ruth Oliver (rutholiver@bren.ucsb.edu)
2024-07-25 19:47:38

*Thread Reply:* fun game! guessing based on order of magnitude based on my analysis of Wildlife Insights... total ~ 1B this year ~ 10 million

👍 Dan Morris
Mitchell Rogers (mitchell.rogers@auckland.ac.nz)
2024-07-25 20:00:40

*Thread Reply:* How about the number of publications on Scopus that mention "Camera trap" (5,457) multiplied by some arbitrarily chosen multiple (200,000) = 1,091,400,000 camera trap images in total. And for the last year I will guess that many of the existing camera traps are still collecting images and many studies are going to be publishing data collected across multiple years so I will use a new multiple (140,000), and there might be around ~824 studies this year based on the equation my Excel plot fit to the number of studies per year so 824**140,000 = 115,360,000. I think I am completely off on the second number... 😅📸

👍 Dan Morris
Tiziana Gelmi Candusso (tiziana.gelmi@gmail.com)
2024-07-25 21:23:20

*Thread Reply:* If we got 1M in Toronto from 33 cameras with continuous sampling of 1 year. Based on this we’d only need 10 urban studies to reach 10M this year 😅

👍 Dan Morris
Dan Morris (agentmorris@gmail.com)
2024-07-26 20:03:53

*Thread Reply:* OK my guesses... the one variable I can put some bounds on is "number of images processed with AI every year". Let's call that NAI. I can put a pretty tight lower bound on NAI for recent years at ~200M, and a looser upper bound at ~400M. I'm sure that's growing, but it's roughly consistent over the last couple of years, I think, at least within an order of magnitude. That also doesn't mean the images processed with AI in, e.g., 2023 were collected in 2023 (they weren't), but I generally don't think it's the case that latency is changing a ton over time.

I can't really even try to estimate the percentage of total images that end up being processed with AI, but I've tried (mostly unsuccessfully) to estimate the number of ecologists/projects using AI, via the time-tested method of "ask random people at ecology conferences whether they use AI". At steady state, publications will be a very good indicator for this ratio, but I think we're still within publication latency of almost anyone using AI, so I don't think the publication record will be a good indicator of this ratio until maybe 2026. But FWIW, I put this number at maybe 5%-10%. Those tend to be high-volume users, so I think maybe 20% of all images collected recently end up being processed with AI. So I would guess maybe NAI/0.2 == between 1B and 2B images are collected per year for conservation and ecology.

If I search Amazon for consumer camera traps, and look at the rough number of products and reviews, and read random Web pages about the percentage of people who write reviews, I'm guessing that the number of consumer camera traps (usually "trail camera" in consumer parlance) that are out in the universe is somewhere in the low tens of millions, heavily biased toward recent years. My guess is that most of those are used briefly and discarded after a few thousand images, but maybe that's another 1B images per year.

So, my guess is 2B-3B images per year in the last couple of years.

And I would guess that with falling storage costs and the availability of consumer cameras, image rates are growing so fast that everything before ~10 years ago is probably negligible in the total count. So I'm guessing maybe 20B camera trap images exist in the universe.

😲 Mitchell Rogers, Alexander Merdian-Tarko
👍:skin_tone_3: Alan Stenhouse
💥 Thor Veen
Anna Willoughby (arwill19@gmail.com)
2024-08-27 22:44:59

*Thread Reply:* Have there been efforts to dig up historic camera trap data and preserve it? Blown away that camera trap studies have been happing since the 90s (or earlier?)? I asked an author for an image from a 2003 paper. They spent some time looking, but alas images were lost. If we don't ask now we may lose some of the early stuff forever.

Roni Choudhury (roni.choudhury@kitware.com)
2024-07-25 19:30:22

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fermi_problem 🙂

} Wikipedia (https://en.wikipedia.org/)
Fermi problem
In physics or engineering education, a Fermi problem (or Fermi quiz, Fermi question, Fermi estimate), also known as a order-of-magnitude problem (or order-of-magnitude estimate, order estimation), is an estimation problem designed to teach dimensional analysis or approximation of extreme scientific calculations. Fermi problems are usually back-of-the-envelope calculations. The estimation technique is named after physicist Enrico Fermi as he was known for his ability to make good approximate calculations with little or no actual data. Fermi problems typically involve making justified guesses about quantities and their variance or lower and upper bounds. In some cases, order-of-magnitude estimates can also be derived using dimensional analysis.
Original URL: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fermi_problem
❤️ Jon Van Oast
👍 Dan Morris
Ben Weinstein (benweinstein2010@gmail.com)
2024-08-02 14:05:14

While I was at ACGI with many great people from this channel (nice job @Sara Beery and David for organizing), one of the needs that came up from land managers in the West is livestock detection on public lands. I thought this would exist already. Does anyone know of an airborne cattle/horse detector. Quick google searches shows plenty of papers (https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/pdf/10.1080/01431161.2019.1624858, and 20+ others https://scholar.google.com/scholar?start=20&q=livestock+detection+object+detection+uav&hl=en&as_sdt=0,38), but no open source implementation that anything like a non-researcher would use. I'm going to just follow this with one of my students for a couple days if anyone wants to get involved, I write each of those authors and try to organize the data. Then it would be interesting to apply to NAIP data in the west and see what happens. If anyone has experience in large scale NAIP processing, I welcome ideas on how best to do it.

👀 Stephanie O'Donnell

Stephanie O'Donnell (stephanie.odonnell@wildlabs.net)
2024-08-12 10:47:32

*Thread Reply:* You could ping our community ben, see if there is data that comes back? Try a discussion here - https://wildlabs.net/groups/ai-conservation

wildlabs.net
AI for Conservation | WILDLABS
Artificial intelligence is increasingly being used in the field to analyse information collected by wildlife conservationists, from camera trap and satellite images to audio recordings. AI can learn how to identify which photos out of thousands contain rare species; or pinpoint an animal call out of hours of field recordings - hugely reducing the manual labour required to collect vital conservation data.
Original URL: https://wildlabs.net/groups/ai-conservation

Ian Ocholla (ian.ocholla@helsinki.fi)
2024-08-16 02:03:27

*Thread Reply:* @Ben Weinstein we have cattle dataset from manned aircraft done in Kenya but yet to make data public at the moment. I am interested in the idea https://doi.org/10.3390/rs16162929

MDPI
Livestock Detection and Counting in Kenyan Rangelands Using Aerial Imagery and Deep Learning Techniques
Accurate livestock counts are essential for effective pastureland management. High spatial resolution remote sensing, coupled with deep learning, has shown promising results in livestock detection. However, challenges persist, particularly when the targets are small and in a heterogeneous environment, such as those in African rangelands. This study evaluated nine state-of-the-art object detection models, four variants each from YOLOv5 and YOLOv8, and Faster R-CNN, for detecting cattle in 10 cm resolution aerial RGB imagery in Kenya. The experiment involved 1039 images with 9641 labels for training from sites with varying land cover characteristics. The trained models were evaluated on 277 images and 2642 labels in the test dataset, and their performance was compared using Precision, Recall, and Average Precision (AP0.5–0.95). The results indicated that reduced spatial resolution, dense shrub cover, and shadows diminish the model’s ability to distinguish cattle from the background. The YOLOv8m architecture achieved the best AP0.5–0.95 accuracy of 39.6% with Precision and Recall of 91.0% and 83.4%, respectively. Despite its superior performance, YOLOv8m had the highest counting error of −8%. By contrast, YOLOv5m with AP0.5–0.95 of 39.3% attained the most accurate cattle count with RMSE of 1.3 and R2 of 0.98 for variable cattle herd densities. These results highlight that a model with high AP0.5–0.95 detection accuracy may struggle with counting cattle accurately. Nevertheless, these findings suggest the potential to upscale aerial-imagery-trained object detection models to satellite imagery for conducting cattle censuses over large areas. In addition, accurate cattle counts will support sustainable pastureland management by ensuring stock numbers do not exceed the forage available for grazing, thereby mitigating overgrazing.
Original URL: https://doi.org/10.3390/rs16162929
Ben Weinstein (benweinstein2010@gmail.com)
2024-08-16 10:27:45

*Thread Reply:* Great, I’m away for the weekend, but be back on Monday. As I’ve said to others, this is very much just a service for the community, blog post kind of idea. And so I’m happy to follow whatever data restrictions you need. We can always circle back and talk about authorship, etc., if this ever turns into something more proper. At this point, I doubt it.

Ben Weinstein (benweinstein2010@gmail.com)
2024-09-21 10:57:00

Does anyone know of python module for automating the download of images from iNaturalist open dataset for a list of target taxa? https://github.com/inaturalist/inaturalist-open-data/tree/documentation, should I write up a few tools, or is it better to go through the released computer vision dataset and see if you taxa is in there. That means downloading alot of data. Imagine I have 30 taxa and I want 1000 images for each.

Chris Lange (s2125675@ed.ac.uk)
2024-09-22 13:38:21

*Thread Reply:* I don't know of anything unfortunately, but it sounds very useful if you do find something!

Elizabeth Campolongo (e.campolongo479@gmail.com)
2024-09-23 10:40:21

*Thread Reply:* We have a couple tools for this type of purpose: Distributed-downloader is larger scale for use on an HPC with MPI. We used it to download the GBIF monthly snapshot as it's geared toward multiple servers and a fast download. cautious-robot is a simpler downloader designed to just download line by line from a CSV (on a laptop), but you could set it up to be distributed manually.

🙌 Chris Lange, Sara Beery
Elizabeth Campolongo (e.campolongo479@gmail.com)
2024-09-23 10:48:47

*Thread Reply:* If you're using metadata from GBIF, I think these would still require downloading rather large zips just to get the URLs unless you did a search to reduce to the taxa of interest.

🙌 Chris Lange
Tom Wye (Fishial.ai) (twye@fishial.ai)
2024-09-25 00:54:33

inat_scraper.py

Morgan Ziegenhorn (she/they) (maziegenhorn36@gmail.com)
2024-10-02 12:01:40

Hi! New to the group and happy to be here 🙂 I've got a question for other BirdNET users: has anyone attempted to adjust BirdNET for sampling rates other than 48 kHz? I'm using BirdNET for transfer learning, and the network I've built on top of it is made entirely from (and will be used on) data sampled at 16 kHz. BirdNET resamples everything to 48 kHz, and I'm wondering if performance might be better if it didn't. From an image perspective with a 0-24 kHz spectrogram, everything from 8-24 kHz is essentially 'blank' in my data- doesn't that impede training compared to a 0-8 kHz image where every pixel contains relevant information? Or should it not matter? And yes, I am aware that spectrograms /= images, just using 'image' as a placeholder. Thanks in advance for any perspectives on this!

👍 Aakash Gupta
Matt Weldy (matthewjweldy@gmail.com)
2024-10-02 19:21:08

*Thread Reply:* BirdNET's spectrogram(s) only go up to 15kHz, despite a Nyquist frequency of 24k. But the spectrogram is hard coded as a layer in the model package so you can't really tinker with it much (unless your going to go deep in teasing apart the saved model files). You could speedup your data by ignoring the sampling rate and feeding it in 160,000 samples at a time, without resampling, but it would shift your target sounds up the frequency scale.

👍 Morgan Ziegenhorn (she/they)
Morgan Ziegenhorn (she/they) (maziegenhorn36@gmail.com)
2024-10-03 09:31:18

*Thread Reply:* thanks for the reply!!

Morgan Ziegenhorn (she/they) (maziegenhorn36@gmail.com)
2024-10-03 10:07:30

*Thread Reply:* I ended up trying something similar to what the BattyBirdNET team is doing- you can change your sample rate and sample length in the config file, so long as sample rate * sample length = 144000 (for regular birdNET, 48000*3 = 144000). For my data, this means that I'm now dealing with classifications on 9 second segments instead of 3 second ones. Jury is still out on whether this made much of a performance difference.

Matt Weldy (matthewjweldy@gmail.com)
2024-10-03 11:50:25

*Thread Reply:* Just be aware that doing so is shifting your sounds up the frequency scale and may be pushing them our of the receptive range for BirdNET

Morgan Ziegenhorn (she/they) (maziegenhorn36@gmail.com)
2024-10-03 11:53:28

*Thread Reply:* 👍 👍 performance was essentially the same, in any case, so I don't think I'll be pursuing that particular option any further 🤷‍♀️

Matt Weldy (matthewjweldy@gmail.com)
2024-10-03 12:06:07

*Thread Reply:* You may want to try a different embedding model to see if a different embedding works better for your target sound. Something like Perch, SurfPerch, or even yamnet/vggish (which both work with audio at a lower sampling rate)

❤️ Morgan Ziegenhorn (she/they)
Morgan Ziegenhorn (she/they) (maziegenhorn36@gmail.com)
2024-10-03 12:10:40

*Thread Reply:* thanks! I would like to, but I'm getting pressure to move forward from my supervisors. So it may be time to just figure out how we can best work with what we have, at this point. It's definitely not bad, just not as perfect as I would've hoped 😛

Matt Weldy (matthewjweldy@gmail.com)
2024-10-03 12:14:48

*Thread Reply:* Over optimizing on your evaluation set might not be ideal anyways. The variance in model performance on different distributions (different sites, years, etc) of real data will probably be larger than any marginal gains your scraping for by finetuning birdnets sampling rate.

Morgan Ziegenhorn (she/they) (maziegenhorn36@gmail.com)
2024-10-03 12:15:38

*Thread Reply:* yeah, that's very well said

Sara Beery (sbeery@caltech.edu)
2024-10-15 16:15:37

*Thread Reply:* @Ben Weinstein @Ben Koger

Josh Veitch-Michaelis (j.veitchmichaelis@gmail.com)
2024-10-15 16:26:25

*Thread Reply:* Do you need a camera trap model, or an aerial one?

Not open source yet, but I have a bunch of thermal imagery for ungulates that I've been meaning to release for a while (FLIR Duo Pro). Several drone flights over UK landscapes so not likely to transfer to other places - we did some flight trials in Nanyuki, Kenya and found that it's basically impossible outside dawn/dusk because the ground heats up so much. It would be easy to retrain a more recent model as this was quite a long time ago.

adam dunlop (adunlop621@gmail.com)

*Thread Reply:* Ours is in Maui county. We’re looking for an aerial model - the data we have was taken from a helicopter and the video is pretty shaky, but the animals stand out fairly well from the rest of the background.

Elizabeth Bondi-Kelly (ecbk@umich.edu)

*Thread Reply:* I was going to refer you to Josh too 🙂 here is the dataset I worked on, taken at various places in Africa: https://lila.science/datasets/conservationdrones. more details here: https://teamcore.seas.harvard.edu/files/teamcore/files/2020_07_teamcore_wacv_birdsai.pdf

LILA BC
Conservation Drones - LILA BC
Overview Monitoring of protected areas to curb illegal activities like poaching is a monumental task. Real-time data acquisition has become easier with advances in unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) and sensors like TIR cameras, which allow surveillance at night when poaching typically occurs. However, it is still a challenge to accurately and quickly process large amounts...
Written by
lilawp
Est. reading time
4 minutes
Original URL: https://lila.science/datasets/conservationdrones
